14190877.review:
Crawl es una de las mejores propuestas de entretenimiento multijugador cooperativo que existen en estos momentos en tu biblioteca, ¿Es que acaso no está en tu biblioteca de Steam aún? Déjame explicarte porque estas tardando en comprarlo…

La idea es simple, por menos de 10 euros este juego indie te da la oportunidad de perder a cada uno de los amigos con los que juegues al Crawl en una trepidante orgia de destrucción, traiciones y sangre en formato pixel nostalgia.

Uno de los jugadores tomara el papel de un aventurero deseoso de escapar de las oscuras mazmorras donde ha sido atrapado, y el resto, el de hasta tres fantasmas hambrientos por acabar con el aventurero y robarle su humanidad, y su posibilidad de huir de la mazmorra. 

Crawl te ofrece infinitas horas de juego con tus amigos (o incluso solo, si prefieres el ostracismo social), la opción de desbloquear nuevo contenido en cada partida, disfrutar controlando docenas de temibles criaturas y mortales trampas, mejorar a tu aventurero al comprarle nuevas armas y habilidades e incluso acabar en épicas batallas finales contra gigantescos monstruos ¡Y todo esto en partidas de menos de una hora!

Créeme, desde que tengo este juego mis amigos me envían anónimos deseando mi desgracia personal y se niegan a hablarme, pero siguen viniendo a casa a quemarse las retinas delante de la pantalla y machacarse los dedos jugando al Crawl. Nos odiamos, si, pero nunca nos hemos divertido tanto.

[b]Si te gusta la acción trepidante, las mecánicas bien engrasadas, la demencia de los cooperativos-competitivos y la estética retro pixel, Crawl es tu juego.[/b]

Si no te gustan, Crawl también deberia ser tu juego.

Como defecto destacaría que actualmente tan solo dispone de multijugador local, pero que eso no te eche para atrás. Recuerda que por algo aún se encuentra en “Early Acess”.

¿Te he dicho que tu aventurero puede correr enloquecido por la habitación mientras vomita indiscriminadamente por el suelo? ¿No? pues ahí tienes otro motivo para comprarte el Crawl.

14172631.review:
这游戏太有意思了！自己一个人和ai打了好久。
游戏风格有些黑暗，但依然无法掩盖这游戏的欢乐，爽快，和有新意。

游戏里玩家各自为一个幽灵，有一个玩家是英雄。英雄踏入地宫进入每个房间冒险，每个房间里会有几个魔法阵，作为幽灵的玩家可以在魔法阵里变换成随即一个怪物，每个怪物的攻击方式和技能都不同。勇者可以考购买装备来加强，怪物也可以在每局结束后进化。在没有成为怪物或者被杀掉的情况下，玩家也可以操纵房间内的各种机关骚扰英雄。
游戏最有创意的部分在于，每当一个操纵勇者的玩家被击杀，击杀者会重新成为英雄，但并不继承之前那为英雄的装备。这也是这个游戏的欢乐之处，想象下，刚刚还是和自己并肩作战的怪物，结果击杀了英雄后变成了另一个英雄，一刀向你砍来。。哈哈哈。
而且作为一款独立游戏，打击感出奇的棒。虽然是非常模糊的像素画面，但人物非常形象。差不多玩一把就能了解所有的游戏机制。如果和朋友一起玩那真是再欢乐不过了。

总之价格实惠，开发者很用心。是款不可多得的精品游戏。

14170511.review:
This is only an Early Access review for C.R.A.W.L., so please keep in mind that everything is subject to change. Hopefully for the better, because I don't see how this game can get any worse.

In this 1 v 3 player game, there is only hero meant to save the world, until his jealous ghost friends stop him. The game fluidly changes from one human fighting off 3 ghosts who summon all manner of atrocities and thirst for his blood, to three "friends" partially wanting to help each other kill the human, but at the same time all those friends are just backstabbers.

With only a dodge roll and sword to start with, dodging traps, buying equipment, crawling through dungeons, leveling up and fighting monsters controlled by other players (unfortunately, unless you are smart enough to just play with bots), playing as the human means juggling three different, unpredictable enemies and traps controlled by jerks who hate you and your life. 

It takes a certain amount of out-of-game problem solving to defeat/overcome the people pretending to be your friend: sometimes your opponents will say their strategy out loud to communicate to each other, but are they speaking in code? Are they trying to use reverse psychology on you (I mean the corner is totally a vulnerable spot right?)? Should you try to con them or will they see right through you? Are they whining about not playing as the human to trick you into losing? Can you just unplug their controllers or throw something at them? How good are you at throat punching? Should you practice throat punching more? Probably. All of these strategies take some serious pondering.

On the business end of the human's bloody sword, playing as the three ghost is intense and gratifying. You can summon and possess all manner of colorful monsters with different play styles and strengths. At the end of every level you gain sweet, sweet hero's blood in order to upgrade these various monsters from lowly skeletons and rats into demon lords, dragons, and beholders (among others and more to come). When not completely wrecking your friend the hero's day as fiendishly awesome monsters, you can ruin your friendship by obliterating them with traps and summoned blobs that auto-attack but can also be possessed. 

While you are happily torturing the poor human you are becoming best friends with your other two friends who aren't a lame human: you are communicating strategies through eye blink Morse code, you are yelling out fake strategies to throw the human off, you are playing dumb to catch them off guard, you are probably even fake-choking to gain the upper hand. All is great, until you realize the human isn't your only competition. And when you realize that everyone in this house sucks at the Heimlich maneuver.

Now you know that those other two bastards are trying to take your rightful kill from you. What the hell is up with that? You were best pals just a second ago, you were like siblings, but now you deserve to be human and they aren't letting you. Now you have to try to trick the other players out of the kill by assuring them that you aren't going to unleash a fountain of fire in order to take the kill, maybe you pretend to miss all of your attacks right until that last sliver of health is begging you to take it.

Then one of two scenarios happens: you get the kill and start the cycle of 1 human v 3 ghosts all over again, or someone else gets the kill and you kick them out of your house and refuse to speak to them again.

I don't recommend playing Caustic Relationships And Wretch Losers (C.R.A.W.L.) unless you want to be alone. If you are already alone, the bots aren't so bad. At least they aren't a bunch of backstabbers. You can always count on red to be your friend....

Seriously though, Crawl, at a most basic level, is incredibly interesting. Part co-op, part competitive, and all fun. It covers a wide audience range by being finely tuned for accessibility while still remaining flexible and deep enough for more serious players to give each other a good challenge. I eagerly look forward to all of the tuning and content updates will bring.

14166453.review:
Review Written on 25/01/2015 (Subject to change) Scroll for Pro's,Cons and Summary.

Do you cherish your relationship with your friends?

THEN DO NOT BUY THIS GAME!

Crawl was made  with the intentions of turning even the strongest of bonds in to heated rivalries; One moment you will find yourself working with others to lower the heroes health, the next you're viciously scrambling to ensure you are the one who delivers  the final blow to take his place.

Crawl offers that which seems to be a rareity in modern games: 4 player local multiplayer. Bringing back the golden days of real couch co-op. The game practically comes gift-wrapped in nostalgia, with its retro-arcade visuals,8-bit audio, two-button combat system and fast-paced gameplay.

Gameplay:

To begin with, you are greeted with an "Insert coin screen" where you must create a character name consisting of three letters. As simple as it sounds, it immediately welcomes you.
 Players  must then  select a god to worhsip. Each offering three different monsters with their own evolution path and starting conditions.

The premise is simple; One player starts as the hero, who must reach level 10 by descending floors to defeat the boss and claim salvation. 

 Sounds easy eh? 

This would be the case, if you didn't have three other players , in ghost form, competing to become the hero in the process, by possessing traps, summoning monsters and deploying slimes. This makes survival as the hero extremely difficult, even more so as the other players gain "Vitae" a currency used to evolve their monsters each time the hero levels up or they draw blood from him.

Fear not though! All is not lost, as each floor contains a blacksmith, where the Hero is able to spend gold they have accumilated through killing monsters, to purchase new weapons, trinkets and powers . However, getting to the shop first on each floor is essential if you want to claim all the best gear before anyone else.

This is where Crawl really shines, it offers a sense of progression. The amount of purchaseable gear is satisfactory, and even after death, any itmes purchased are not lost.  The monsters don't lose out either, as between floors, players are prompted to evolve their monsters, becoming stronger and increasing their chances of killing the hero.

Now, let's discuss one of my favourite aspects of the game: 

Bosses.

Once players have reached level 10, they are able to face a boss, should they choose to do so, by entering the boss room and standing on a glyph. However, you can only have one attempt at the boss per floor, and three overall between everyone. This is when things become interesting, as you need to ensure you are well equipped for the battle, but have to accept the fact that persuing better gear always comes with the risk of dying and not becoming the hero again, allowing others to face the boss. 

Here's the brilliant part; Once the boss fight begins, any player who is not the hero is able to possess one of the bosses body parts such as the arms and head. Each limb will have a different attack, meaning cooperation and coordination is essential.

 If the hero prevails, the player wins the game, If the hero is to fail, he will be sent back to the floor with little health and the game continues. If all boss attempts have been used and the hero dies on the final attempt, it's game over. The winner being decided by whoever has accumilated the most XP during the game...Oh and the hero's character is permanently lost, although there seems to be no real penalty for this as there is nothing tying you to your character post-game. You can literally create another character with the same name straight after. To counter this, me and my buddies came up with a system where if your character dies, you can no longer use that three letter name again. Not much of a loss, but better than what the system currently offers.

With the completion of each game, win or fail, you earn unlocks. Wether it be new traps, new evolutions for your monsters, weapons , tomes etc.... This adds to the games already enormous amount of replayability. (After 15 hours of play I still haven't unlocked everything!)

Mechanics:

The game plays best with a controller, although a mouse and keyboard is entirely useable. The two-button system is easy to use; you have a primary and secondary attack and a stick for movement, although the mouse can also used for movement; your character will move to where the cursor is pointed. I found the mouse a little more tedious and difficult to use as opposed to the gamepad.
 The fighting system is easy to understand, the difficulty comes from avoiding attacks and timing.  Personally, I'd like to be able to carry a ranged and a melee weapon and have another button to switch between the two.
 All in all, due to the simplicity of the controls, combat feels fluent and tight, with the animations complimenting and completing the system. 


Multiplayer:

Be prepared for cursing, shouting, physical violence and possibly a heart attack-enduced death as you work extremely hard to bring the heroes health down only to have a friend steal the kill and become the hero. 

This game is best experienced with friends. You can of course play solo, the A.I is more than capable of providing a decent challenge, and is surpringly believeable, making human-like errors. But local couch multiplayer is the heart and soul of this game, and besides, there's no better feeling than defeating your friends and claiming salvation.

Unfortunately, at the time of this review, Online multiplayer is not currently implemented. This is a shame because me and my buddies aren't always together, and we'd love to get some Crawl on when this is the case. Fingers crossed though!

Another feature I would love to see in this game is Steam Workshop intergration. I'm sure modders would have a blast creating massive amounts of content. This would no doubt increase the lifespan of Crawl.

Graphics and audio:

Crawl is certainly a pretty game. From the intentional graphical glitches at the main menu, to the colourful displays of attacks ,traps, monsters and blood spills. The pixelated aesthetics feel right at home and sit comfortably amongst the haunting 8-bit track that accompanies them. The randomly generted dungeons  can get a little samey, but there is enough diversity to keep things interesting and the developers have confirmed that dungeon generation, music,  monsters, traps, items and a whole plethora of content will be added. 

Issues

Naturally, being in early access, Crawl is not without it's flaws; Ghosts being dragged too quickly from the last room into the next when the hero is running through them, sometimes resulting in the inability to utilise a room filled with traps. The occasional door refusing to let you pass or objects disappearing and reappearing. But these are problems that can easily be ironed out; over the 15 hours I've played, I had only encountered a few of these issues and rarely did they hinder the experience.



Pro's:
-4 playerLocal multiplayer
-Progression system/RPG Elements
-Brilliant premise; friends play as monsters 
-Fast-paced gameplay
-Lot's of content
-Replayiblity
-Feels polished
-Easy to jump straight in
-Gorgeous pixel art
-Strong mechanics
-Low system requirements
-More content to come

Cons:
-No Steam Workshop
-No online Multiplayer
-You will put Friendships to the test
-Occasional bugs

Summary:

Crawl feels incredibly well-polished for an early access game, offering fast-paced gameplay, a unique take on the genre and a level of competitiveness that could only be achieved within it's own universe. 

8.5/10  "Must Buy"

14072137.review:
Awesome couch multiplayer game. Great music and visual imo. Gameplay is in a top down dungeaon crawling game. Main advantage it has is that it is very different compared to other couch multiplayer games. One person is the "hero" whilst others are ghosts going down levels of a dungeon. 
Hero
The aim of the hero is to level up to level 10, activate the portal and defeat the boss monster. The hero can also buy stuff from the black smith and store including weapons, buffs and special ability items. 
Ghosts
The aim of the ghosts is to kill the hero and therefroe become the new hero. They do this by possessing traps and activating pentagrams to become monsters in the dungeon. The ghosts get viae points by other heroes leveling up to spend on evolving their monsters. Their is a good variety of monsters as of v0.3 with more to come. When the monsters hurt the hero they earn blood which they convert to gold to buy stuff when they are the hero.
Boss
Once a hero reaches level 10 they can activate a portal on a dungeon floor, with each floor's portal only allowed to be activated once, to fight the boss. The boss is controlled by the ghost players, eg one boss hass two tentacles and a head  making three control points and one boss has three different heads. If the hero dies they are shunted out. The boss can be fought three times total in a match until the games end.
NO signs of online multiplayer anytime soon but I don't mind as the game has decent AI and I prefer them spend time adding more environements, creatures and bosses.

In the end I would recommend this game if you want a multiplayer game such as towerfall, samurai gun, gang beasts etc mixed with dungeon crawling rouguelike gameplay and assymetric multiplayer like evolve or nintendo land games.

14012636.review:
1st Impressions: Excellent party game, but stands on it's own as good as single player game.  Very, very fun.  Any criticism I have is in no way a deal-breaker.
Pros:
- Balance: Lots of attention seems to be paid to keeping it interesting w/ the power dynamic between players constantly shifting.  Getting your minions' butts kicked? You'll rank up monsters faster. Spent a bunch of time running around as the hero killing everyone else? Now you're reincarnated as an toothpick spitting inchworm. All this is done without feeling like it's simply picking on the person in the lead.
ADDITIONALLY, the end-game is satisfying regardless of outcome since everyone both worked for and against it the entire time.
- Pace: I'm impressed how well it allows for a leveling and item system while still keeping the gogoGOGOGO!GO!GO! mentality.  There always seems to be something for everyone to be doing.
- Mood & Atmosphere: The glitched out voice acting brings me right back to scratchy copies of Golden Axe played on poorly tracking TVs.  Pixel graphics can be an aquired taste, but I think it fits well and this game puts a cool spin on it (this kind of "possessed game cartridge").

Cons (somewhat minor, but I hope can be addressed as the game develops )
- Player confusion: With the unsaturated color palette it can be easy to lose track of your player.  This gets harder during big brawls when some people may be controlling the same type of minion.  Regardless, the learning curve is small.
- Advancement & Unlocks: As it stands, the item and "God" unlocks after a session seem arbitrary.  Currently, they seem to be coming out of the glitched-out ether of the game (which is cool mood-wise), but it might be nice to see as least know what's triggering them - Are they indeed random? Tied to playtime? In-game exploration?

I've only played this a few hours but it is already well worth the price - for the single player experience, let alone the strong party game this is!

The local co-op, retro, throw everyone in the ring and fight each other type games. Stuff like Towerfall, Samurai Gunn, Gang Beasts, Nidhogg, BroForce Deathmatch, etc. Theey're a great style of game for when you have friends over. Everyone can grab a controller and get right to the fun. No wasting time. Crawl adds to this genre in a big way.

The concept is pretty genius. 1 player controls the hero while 3 other players control ghosts which can "pocess" traps and mobs while the hero runs from room to room in the dungeon. The fun exists because the hero needs to kill the monsters to collect XP and level up. Once he gets to 10 he needs to find the portal room and portal to the boss. At which point the 3 other players take pocession of different parts of the boss and try to take out the hero and send everyone back into the dungeon. The catch comes when a ghost kills the boss, he then becomes the hero and tried to level up his hero to 10. There are many other things to consider while leveling. Finding blood and turning it in to merchants sos you can buy weapons and spells and potions. Ghosts collect points to level up the monster they can transform into in certain rooms in the dungeon. 

The whole game put together keeps everyone engaged and in it to win it not matter how far behind. First time playing my guy hit level 10 first but I never made it to the boss through the portal room. Another guy made it to the boss several times and died. The guy who ended up winning was in last the entire match. 

I generally do not do EA but this one is a gem. This one should be fun to play for a long time as long as you have some people around to play with.

The Recipe for Crawl goes something like this:
• a dash of inverted D&D (one player, three DMs)
• a sprinkle of Tag
• a cup of Legend of Zelda
• three tablespoons Altered Beast
• 20 pounds of arcade nostalgia

The goal is simple: kill the final boss and regain your humanity. However, there's only one soul to have and four greedy dead paws trying to grab it. Who has the humanity now? Everybody gang up and kill him. Killing blow takes the soul. This pattern repeats itself until somebody becomes powerful enough to face the final boss. Whether they succeed or not depends on the skill of all involved.

This is some of the best couch entertainment I've seen in a while. It tickles my heart with its presentation, seeming so serious but hinting at its self-awareness.

13467947.review:
WARNING!: COMPLETELY EXPLANATORY, MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS!

If this game had existed on the SNES or the Genesis or even Personal Computers in 1995, I'm not sure anyone would have played any other game. 

The concept is truly original. Up to four players can play at a time. 1-3 play as the spirits inhabiting the dungeon, and they attempt to destroy the Hero who is trying to conquer the dungeon by controlling traps and summoning monsters. The more blood from the Hero that each spirit spills, the more they can offer to the gods in exchange for gold. Once the Hero is defeated, the spirit who delivered the killing blow now takes his place. The new Hero can take all the blood spilled from the old hero as an offering and receive gold which can buy new items like weapons, spell tomes, potions, armor, and charms. This essentially leads to a race for level 10 as the Hero. However, at the end of each floor, for each level the Hero has risen, the spirits are given points to level their monsters. Whom ever can level their hero form to 10 can open the portal to the final boss, Kurok. Kurok can be controlled by all three spirit players simultaneously, and will provide and extreme challenge to the Hero with weapons like toxic sludge, trap bubbles, and a humongous eye laser. Each run of the game, no matter who attempts to defeat Kurok, there can only be three attempts to defeat Kurok before he unleashes his wrath upon the world. If all three attempts fail, Kurok will break lose, and all players lose. The lowest scoring player of the game has their in-game profile permanently erased.

Whilst I still have not unlocked every God in the game, this has become my favorite party game ever. When you find yourself smiling at the person who is playing Hero, saying to them "I'm definitely going to kill you", it creates a special moment. This game has created the most friendly gamer rivalry I have ever experienced. The localized experience that the players get is absolutely incredible. It does not take long to understand how the game works. Then, after about 8 hours of  play, the participants can still find themselves discovering new items popping up in the blacksmith shop.

I still find this game incredible, and I've recommended it to many friends. We all agree, it creates the best and most friendly kind of game rivalry we have ever experienced.

[b]Gripes:[/b]

[b]Postive notes about the game:[/b]

[b]Possible additions to the game:[/b]
Death pits! Lava bits! Water world. (Different wall sprites, it does get monotonous after 11 floors to see the same green decaying stone walls.)
Holster/switch weapons? Most game controllers have more than 4 buttons...
Throw mechanic for player? Throw props? Hide in them?

More than one final boss?

YOU'RE DEAD WRONG

Crawl may only have short play sessions and generally simple gameplay, however, the experience that is delivered throughout that short period of time is like no other. You play as the monsters to regain your humanity or fight as a human to keep your humanity. This extremely unique multiplayer experience cannot be overlooked. The only real problem comes in with...limited multiplayer options. Fighting AI controlled bots is more entertaining than you might think however, the serious problem arises with there being only local multiplayer. Cons:

13033654.review:
An Absolutely outstanding game. 

I walked into this game being a little skeptical of the promise and ambition the the trailer highlighted, but I was so, so plesently surprised.

unlike most indie games still in alpha this game has an amazing level of polish to it. After several hours of playing I have not once experienced a single crash or significant bug. The fighting is also incredibly balanced and the player and monsters never feel ridiculously powerful or impossible to kill. you never die from a cheap shot and every bit of damage you take feels like you could have avoided it. it has a very Dark-Souls-Esk feel to the combat, its fast, fluid, responsive and satisfying and you never feel punished for dying.

 Additionally, if you have no buddies to play with the, AI is superb, acting much like a human does in how it moves, fights and decides to buy items (pausing for a brief moment to think). having the choice to alter the amount of players (from 2 to 4) is great and acts as  a subtle way of modifing the difficulty in addition to the AI also has a difficulty modifyer.

controllers also have complete compatability, very literally plug and play. either it be a 360 or ps3. (I cannot confirm for other controllers, but it seems to be the case)

but when you have 4 controllers, the computer hooked up to the big screen and a few beers around, this game absolutely shines. even in alpha this game is honestly brilliant.


BUGS
These are the only bugs that I have noticed thus far (and they are pretty minor ones at that).

1. as a ghost you can fly around the map collecting ectoplasm. when you collect enough you can spawn upwards of 3 slimes to enter the field at any time. they are weak, but can certainly be an effective distraction, causing surprising damage if not delt with. 

There appears to be a spawning bug, you can place them anywhere on the field  however placing them too close to a wall or corner will result in them getting stuck and unable to move. This is no problem as they are easily cleaned up and the game can continoue, but this will probably be quite easily fixed in later versions.


2. The AI. while acting pretty reasonable most of the time and are certainly a worthy challenge (I am yet to win a watch against simply 2 AI on normal, I cant imagine what 3 on hard would be like). 

they do, ever so rarely get a little confused if there is alot of gunk on the floor. As they try to avoid it they end up running over it multiple times and take significant amount of damage figuring out how to behave (but they do snap out of it eventually) . yet, so far, this has only happened maybe 2-3 times in the many matches I have played and only seem to last for that room. its a rare occurance and will probably be patched at a later date.


but apart from that.....nothing of mention, the game is very well polished. very easily worth the asking price.

12808894.review:
This game is a gem of local co-op fun and chaos.

I took about 30-40 minutes per game with 2 humans and 1-2 AI players, and the game pacing felt about right. Crawl itself has a crazy simple design, looks and feels like an old arcade game (only 2 buttons, and one stick) I played with a controller and loved it (haven't yet tried the mouse). As simple as it was on paper, playing the hero took some work (monsters actually felt more responsive and intuitive, controllwise, than the hero), aiming ranged weapons took finesse, and missing a special or crucial attack because the target was moving around was heartbreaking, but  each time I moved to deny either my friend or the AI my precious humanity was a moment of absolute triumph. The cutscenes between hero death and the new hero entering the game gave the unfortunate loser a chance to exclaim thier losses, while the winner exclaimed thier victory.

The Games basic premise is refreshing, with 4 players all competeing for the chance to be a hero and defeat the boss. The switch off between being the hero, a monster, a trap and a ghost was enjoyable. Best moment was when I realized that the final boss was also controlled by the ghosts, and I took great pleasure in shooting my friend with a simple, but really enjoyable array of attacks. The ghosts will need to work together to take down the hero, because although they outnumber him, most of the time the hero has more health, and often does more damage (depending on monster level), when an AI hero battle began my friend and I would quickly talk strategy and each try to exploit the hero's predicament in order to land the final blow ourselves.

The chaotic and quick pace that ensued was enjoyed by all, and even though we didn't win the match, simply playing the game was enjoyable.  Finaly, after finishing the match we got to see the new items we unlocked for our next game, I can't wait to try and find them all.

For an early access game feels both polished, and nuanced.

8.9/10, can't wait to see what this game becomes!

EDIT: With New Bosses, New Monsters and Tons More to Explore I am more excited than ever to keep on exploring the dungeon.. I got goosebumps when I saw the release trailer, and I can honestly say that I expect the next few evenings are going to be spent in the company of friends trying to brutally murder each in CRAWL.

12700053.review: Explosively good. The kind of experience that makes you want to arrange an in-person handshake. The gameplay is moment to moment satisfaction: your attacks make big loud noises whenever you smack a foe around, making the whole experience incredibly active. Not to mention the thrill of negotiating when to dodge, when to attack, what monster to take out first and what traps you THINK you can jump over. And all the while, big bright numbers are popping up whenever you score a hit, level up, collect gold, etc. The music builds and travels around you in a way that makes you feel like you're traveling further and further into something dangerous. Unlockables always make you want to play a second match, and there is an amazing amount of variety here for just ten dollars. All of the monsters and their evolution chains will bring a whole new slant to the way you fight, with some creatures bringing straight-up entirely NEW mechanics to gameplay that are exclusive to them. There's only one monster that can summon low level zombies. Only one monster that can heal itself and other monsters. Only one monster that can summon a gust of wind to move the hero into the path of a trap. Only one monster whose eye can be used as a weapon after you kill it! Bottom line, when love is behind the making of a game, you can tell right away. And the result is bombastically fun. Mighty fine balance that gives advantages to both being the ghost and being the hero, with both roles always presenting opportunities that will permanently better a player's position. The final boss is gorgeous and puts up a fight that will make you chomp your lip and raise your fist. This whole game will make you chomp your lip and raise your fist. Pummel-loving gameplay with an AD&D monstrous manual vibe that will make you smile. Would reccomend

12659426.review:
Crawl caught me entirely by surprise. The concept, gameplay and art style were all so fresh and unique that I was immediately hooked by this game. There are too few games in the world today that evoke the same emotions as the quest involved in playing a round of Crawl with your friends.
Firstly, as an early access game, I was astonished when I picked this up because I found little to no glitches or bugs and it was bursting with content right from the start. The community is also very much alive and the developers are simply phenomenal, always keeping you updated as to their progress and ideas for the game. 
The gameplay is like nothing I've ever played with up to 4 players playing locally (3 as ghosts and one as a hero) attempting to become a level 10 hero and defeat the dungeons boss. The catch is that since there is only one hero at a time, if you are not playing as the hero, you are one of the 3 ghosts controlling the dungeons minions, traps and bosses attempting to kill the hero and whomever deals the killing blow becomes the next hero.
Games are generally fast-paced and frenetic yet the overall game round can take up to 30-40 minutes to play through depending on the players experience levels. The fact that the game is truly semi-cooperative in nature at all times is wonderful and keeps player interaction high. This is what makes local multiplayer gaming so wonderful to me and Crawl really delivers on that front. Many gamers have argued that they wished this game offered online support, and while I understand that not everybody has the opportunity to play with 4 players locally I really don't think this game would deliver the same experience if it were being played with people miles away on the internet instead  of your friends and family on the couch next to you.
While I absolutely love this game and how unique and just plain fun it is the one major frustration for me would have to be the fact that the monster who deals the killing blow becomes the next hero and not the monster who dealt the most damage or some other qualifier. This just seems unintuitive, unfair and unrewarding to the non-hero players and I really think this should at least be an alternative option for the game settings if not the standard. I have discussed this with other gamers and while I understand their points as to how making it the player who deals the last blow can work as a balancing mechanism for weaker players I've seen it create just as much imbalance and more importantly change the flow of play to where camping is encouraged for monsters so that they can prepare themselves to deal the killing blow instead of simply attack the hero relentlessly. I truly believe that there should at least be an alternative option available in the settings for the monster who dealt the most damage to become the hero because I find it silly for a game to inherently make one of its mechanics just frustrating for the players  and immediately turn them off the excitement.
Despite my one major criticism I have seldom found a game whose development has excited me as much as this one and I really hope that the developers consider my opinions on the game. Overall Crawl is definitely a game worth checking out for any gamer who wants to experience a new and exciting type of game and I highly recommend it if like me you are a huge fan of local multiplayer games that appeal to that childhood sense of playing arcade games and other video games side to side with your friends and family before the lonely Online Gaming era.

12652017.review:
This game is great! The graphics really aren't too bad, and besides, I vastly prefer well-made 2D graphics to fuzzy, badly made 3D graphics any day. Very fun gameplay, and I like the fact that you can, for once play as the traps as well as the monsters.

 My only real problem with this game is the aiming, and the fact whatever you are shooting goes whichever way you are facing. This makes ranged monsters/heroes feel uncontrollable at times. I would like to see some more content, such as new monsters and equipment, as well as maybe a couple of new traps. I also think the Gatekeeper is a bit easy, and could perhaps have some more health.

Apart from that this game is AWESOME! I highly recommend it to anyone who likes dungeon crawl games, as well as Dungeons and Dragons players. By which I mean, of course, PROPER D&D, the Pen and Paper games, not that stupid Neverwinter game made by Perfect World. That game sucks.

Anyway, DEFINITELY a reccomendation. They are still bringing out more content for about another year, and after that the price is going up, probably to this games actual worth, about $20. Definitely get it soon!

12310840.review:
Ранній доступ... Зазвичай я скептично відношусь до проектів у ранньому доступі, і переважно не купую їх на ранніх стадіях розробки. Але ще з першого трейлера я закохався в Crawl, з нетерпінням чекав релізу і зразу ж придбав.

Crawl - це дуже динамічний і веселий мультиплеєрний роуглайк для <чотирьох гравців (можна і з ботами). 
Основною ідєю гри є конкуренція між гравціми: На початку забігу один з гравців стає героєм, всі ж інші - духами, головною ціллю яких є вбивство того самого героя. Духи повинні шукати в кімнатах пентаграми, ставши на які вони перетворюються на одного з трьох монстрів, вибраних на початку гри. Вони всі різні, мають різні типи атак і стратегію битви. Їх, до речі, можна прокачувати по різних гілках в дереві еволюції. Також духи можуть вселятись в різноманітні пастки, рандомно розставлені по кімнатах. 
Гравець, який вбиває героя - сам стає героєм і продовжує його шлях. Гра за нього теж не позбавлена варіативності. Тут вам і різні типи зброї, і спец. навики, і підсилення та магічні ефекти (прокачка і еквіп індивідуальні, для кожного з гравців). Тому  цікаво грати, як за людину, так і за "мобів".
Ціль героя - дойти до боса, яким, спільними силами, будуть керувати інші гравці і перемогти його, маючи лише три спроби. Одна спроба на поверх. На жаль, бос покищо тільки один, але це ж ранній доступ.
UPD: тепер уже два.

Графіка ІМХО шикарна. Якщо придивлятись і придератись - можна сказати, що занадто мало деталізації, пікселі занадто великі і занадто піксельні. Але я так не скажу, бо мене графіка повністю влаштовує. 

Ще дуже порадувало, що вже через два місяці після релізу - вийшло перше доповнення, в якому додано ще чотирьох монстрів і купа дрібних фіксів, які роблять гру зручнішою і приємнішою.

Єдиним мінусом на даний момент є те, що доступний тільки локальний кооператив. Розробники обіцяють, що найближчого часу вийде обновлення, що дозволить грати вже через інтернет, але це ще тільки в планах.

[h1]=[/h1]
В результаті отримуємо перспективний проект, з бодрим геймплеєм, приємною графікою і оригінальною задумкою.
Вживати Crawl рекомендую виключно в компанії друзів.

12273197.review:
Last night I had some friends over at my place for dinner and afterwards we decided to play a round of Crawl. 

We had such a load of fun! We had 4 players, 2 with xbox controller, 1 with the xbox controller from the guitar hero drumkit and one (who despises controllers) on the keyboard. First they made the mandatory jokes about the pixely graphics and how it made their eyes bleed, but in the end the gameplay really made up for it. 

So, in this rogue-like game you are an adventurer trying to survive a maze of rooms and monsters (your friends) on a quest to defeat Kurok, the final boss. So while you are making your way through the rooms, your friends control incorporeal ghosts that can spawn monsters and possess traps. In some rooms pentagrams appear that allow a ghost to materialize into one of his monsters (randomly chosen) and try to gain back his mortality by defeating the hero. The one who delivers the final blow gets to play the hero.

Overall, everyone got to play the hero for a while.. except me. But that's actually not a bad thing! Once you reach the trapdoor of a floor you get to the next stage and before starting, every player can upgrade his monsters. You get upgrade points (or "vitae") based on how many levels the other players gained, which means that if you didn't get to play the hero, you should get a lot of vitae to make your monsters a lot stronger. I really like this mechanic, but it didn't work out that well for us, since my friends still had pretty strong monsters as well (until I got the dragon, muahahah).

With 4 players the game is pretty intense and we had a great laugh. I really recommend playing this game couch-coop.

12270278.review:
Pros:
Hero has various choice of weapons and utilities, and demons have various choice towards upgrading demons. Also somewhat quite indepth with battle system and team work.
"Easy to pick up and play" game.
Well fitting music to atmosphere.

Cons:
Controller is needed for precise aiming.
No online (just yet).

12267346.review:
A great concept of a game carefully crafted and bundled into an easily set up multiplayer game. There is character progression, adversity which shifts constantly as other players take the role of the hero and the others take the role of the monsters trying to turn him into floor paste and some great bosses which allow for some nice action.

Overall, a solid concept. Now the reason for the no recommendation;

I played local multiplayer with a bot or two (not having more than one other person immediately available) and the result was a frantic scrabble after the AI, trying to figure out what to do. This itself did not take long, but the frantic scrabble continued on and on and on. Normally, frantic in a game is good, but this just felt like always playing catch-up and never progressing. At the end of each floor, regardless of character advancement, it always felt like we were not quite sure what had been achieved, what happened or what we were even trying to do. We continued on for a while, had a few boss encounters and played as both the monsters and hero a few times each. It was around the time my friend said "I'm bored" that I realized that I was too and had just been forcing fun onto the session.

The ghost characters constantly felt like they were dragged from room to room, rather than chasing the hero, often never having the chance to even attempt the various awesome traps in the corridoors between some of the rooms. The blob drops were a nice touch, enabling the ghosts to stay in the action, but not overwhelm the hero too much with mobs. But it still felt a bit bland and it was hard to relate to any of the characters with the constant control switch (mostly with the AI bots getting in there 9 times in 10). Overall, for two of us playing with two bots, it was not fun.

Other people with three friends to play with may very well have an awesome time with Crawl, but I think it needs a little more balance, maybe some humor or something, anything to bring it to life. Players need something to work with to get fun out of a game. Other than that, the devs have done an awesome job (love the boss intros, they looked awesome!) and I hope I get chance to have fun with this in the future.

I've followed Crawl before it was on early access, and it really is quite amazing to how they delivered what they promised within the game.


Pros:

 Amazing unique gameplay, that feels fresh and interesting wether you are playing single player or with your friends!

Great balance (especially the release version), all monsters feel relevant and useable, all the questionable weapons have been given tweaks to make them great. The game no longer punishes you for trying different things out and as a result the game feels a lot more open.

Great graphics !!!

Easy to play, Crawl probably has some of the best controller support I've ever witnessed in a game. Furthermore you can have multiple people on keyboards, someone can use a mouse. Heck I've even used a drawing tablet.


Cons:

It is (a lot) more fun to play local co-op than against the AI. 

It Is a dungeon crawl (hence the title of the game), and that can become repetitive if its not your thing.



Playing Crawl with my friends is probably the most fun I've ever had playing a video game ever.

12104114.review:
Crawl is an incredibly interesting multiplayer game. Upon taking the role of the human you are thrust into a dungeon filled with traps and monsters all controlled by people you may or may not know and must fight until you win or die trying. Upon death you become one of three ghosts seeking to end the life of a man in order to claim his humanity, during your quest you may choose to work together as you possess monsters and traps but ultimatly you all strive to be the one to deliver the final blow in order to claim a chance at sweet deliverence.

TLDR: It's a fun multiplayer game where you all beat the shit outta eachother. Unlike other multiplayer games with a small player limit , such as a infamous one which may or may not involve italian plumbers having parties, the game balances power based on how much damage you deal, how much the player has leveled up, and ultimatly makes it feel like you always have a chance to take the game. All in all this game is amazing.

12092069.review:
My first impression of the game while watching the trailer was that the dungeon was filled with monsters that you could take control of as a ghost and the summoning circles were used to summon more powerful monsters. Boy I was wrong. The circles are the only way to summon monsters except for slimes that you can drop as a ghost if you collect enough orbs that float around the screen.

I made the mistake of playing the game with three bots my first go. I was lost the entire game as the bots were too fast to keep up with what was going on most of the time leaving me clueless on how to play the game even at the game over screen. I came in third place and only managed to become a human once as the bots constantly got the last hit on the human after I managed to wear him down.

The second play through I played with one other person and things started making sense. I finally realized I can summon slime, which I may have been doing before but things were so chaotic I didn't know what was going on.

Overall, you should play the game for the first time with 2 players or 1 bot to get the hang of it. While this isn't the best way to play the game, it's easier to learn the ropes.  The more players (once you know what you are doing) the more fun this game becomes.

Despite my misconceptions of the game, I still find it enjoyable especially as a party game with friends. Thumbs up!

11950062.review:
Crawl is a a top-tier couch multiplayer game. It has to be one of the best multiplayer games I've ever played. The game mechanics work seamlessly together to create an experience that had me and all of my friends on the edge of our seats with excitement several times over the course of four or five playthroughs. It's rare that we find a game that keeps us so excited for so long. 

Despite a fairly simple set of mechanics, it manages to keep up the intensity by constantly finding ways to up the ante. The spirit players are consistently evolving their monsters into more powerful forms, but the hero is always gaining more levels and buying loot. Then, when the hero dies the cycle continues for another player. By the time a hero is getting close to level 10 (the required level to fight the boss), the spirits probably have at least one of their monsters at peak evolution--and the peak evolution monsters are almost all bad-ass hero slaying machines. By that point, every encounter is a desperate scramble to see who can hit level 10 first. The players trade off constantly, each getting their turn to be the hero.

Even when someone does hit level 10 and face the boss, the spirits control the boss's various limbs. Good teamwork and coordination can make it incredibly difficult for the hero to succeed; it becomes an intense struggle between the spirits and the hero. Good thing you get 3 chances to beat the boss... but those 3 chances are shared between all players. Some of the most intense moments I've had playing this game came from close calls during the boss fight, but some of the dungeon's rooms can be nearly as treacherous as the boss fight when controlled by good spirit players.

The game keeps things fresh by (I think) randomly generating the dungeon's levels every time you play, along with randomizing the loot you can buy from the store. Every time you play, you get new options, and every time you finish a game you unlock new evolutions, traps, or loot. One of the first unlocks is a laser beam trap that we all came to dread greatly when playing as the hero (and love when playing as a spirit). That thing is awesome. You can even unlock new gods to worship (well, only one right now but I imagine they plan on adding more), which open up new monsters and new evolution paths for your monsters.

Crawl managed to entertain 7 fickle friends for several hours, even though only four of us at a time could play. It was intense enough and fun enough that it was OK to have to be sidelined, because even watching your friends play is a fairly decent experience. It's hard not to pick sides and start rooting for the spirits or the hero, even if you're not playing. We will *definitely* be playing more of this, especially once more content comes out. The fact that they call this game "early access" is incredible. I already feel like I've gotten more than $10 worth of awesome fun out of Crawl, and the fact that more content is coming has me actively excited for more.

11912043.review:
Incredibly fun to play with two or thre friends. Definitely don't recommend playing with one or alone.

Gameplay is like a lightweight, realtime, roguelike, and features one-of-a-kind coopetition. One player starts out as the human, and the others are ghosts trying to kill the human. The ghost that scores the killing blow becomes the human. As the humans level up, the ghosts get to level up as well. The more damage you do to the human (read: the longer you spend as a ghost) the more money you can get by praying to a shrine. With these mechanics the game is amazingly self-balancing.

Do well as a human? Well your ghost is going to be very weak. Finally get to be a human after a long time as a ghost? Go to the store with your oodles of cash and buy the best gear.

Games last between 45min to 1.5 hours. Completing a game unlocks new shop items and ghost abilities to keep you coming back for more.

Really looking forward to what else they add to this game!

11894059.review:
Данная писанина относится к ранней версии игры, так что все отмеченное не положительным будет исправлено разработчиками, скорее всего.
Ну что же, запустив игру, начав "раунд" игрок чуть ли не сразу окунается во всё действие игры. Битвы с монстрами, комнаты с ловушками, в финале 3 попытки на босса. Активно приходится играть всем - и призракам, и человеку. На карте иногда встречаются лечилки, но их количество мало. Это совсем не минус, так как умирать необходимо, чтобы дать возможность отыграться другим игрокам, ну и самому не сильно накормить других опытом для эволюции монстров. Боты довольно глуповаты, причём это сильнее заметно, когда бот играет человеком. Даже на "hard"-режиме игрок обгоняет ботов на 3-4 уровня минимум, что не даёт ему нормально развить своих монстров (к тому времени, как у ботов уже 1 эволюция на 50 vitae и запас небольшой, у игрока в лучшем случае предпосление эволюции, заметно более ослабленные по сравнению со следующей ступенью). Также боты берут первое попавшееся оружие/заклинание с полки, иногда себе во вред. Также слабо боты уворачиваются от босса, нередко просто забегая в пузырь. Разработчики наверняка улучат качество ИИ. Лучше играть с друзьями, это несомненно, т.к. никакой ИИ не заменит живого человека. Хорошая часть с закрытым контентом, открываемым после прохождения/проигрыша раунда, добавляет реиграбельность. На открытие некоторых вещей/монстров может уйти не мало времени, но оно того стоит.
В общем, даже в ранней версии разработчик сделал отличную игру, осталось ждать всяческих дополнений.

11894026.review:
I remember seeing MangaMinx and Boyinaband playing this on Youtube and thinking: "Wow, this actually looks pretty fun!"

So, thinking back to that video, I decided to try and find it. Lo and behold, it was on Steam! I immediately bought, noticing it had a single-player feature as well, something that appealed to me, since I don't have the best Internet in the world. After the fast download, I played it for the first time.

Wow! I had seen gameplay for this game on Youtube, but I never thought it would be soo much fun! Even against the AI, the game itself has a simple yet challenging playstyle to it that I love, and the music and graphics match so well with the action the game can offer!

I have few complaints, to be honest. Normally, I would have a number of them, seeing as this is Early Access, but I only have a few. 

First, it just seems so short. Eight floors just seems so small for a game. But it is in Early Access, so I could understand why.

Secondly, while I enjoyed what I saw so far (I managed to play the AI into losing his Humanity, which was satisfying), maybe adding different kinds of surroundings, like mossy dungeons or dark, dank caves would be possible. It'd be interesting to see how a fight against a mindflayer (or hentai tentacle beast, either way, they're pretty interesting) would go in a cave with floor-to-ceiling rock formations here and there.

And lastly, the weapon selection. While the weapons are useful in different situations, it just seems kinda boring to swing a sword or throw some daggers around. Maybe adding a bow or possibly a staff is possible? It'd certainly change how players played the game.

All-in-all, this is a great game to play with your friends. Everyone is involved in not just the dungeon-crawling levels, but also the final boss, which was pretty interesting.

I've never seen a game like this before, and I'm very much looking forward to seeing how much more is going to go into this game!

EDIT:

After playing the game a few more times, I realized that it DOES include other weapons, as well as other monster elvolutions. My bad for not playing more of the game and securing my knowledge. All it takes is a completion of the game as either the human or the spirit, and those new unlockables are given to you before heading back to the main menu.

EDIT 2:

I'm forgetting or overlooking quite a bit in this game, apparently. I recently discovered a spirit-usable statue feature, which allows spirits to become strong, high-level monsters that would normally be available through monster evolution. It's a pretty interesting concept, and one I kind of dread. A low level player can quickly be eradicated by one of these monstrosities, but the battles are tense and hectic. 

As for other features, I noticed that there are a number of other weapons that are unlocked through continuous play, such as javelins and clubs. Once again, makes play throughs a bit more interesting as time goes on.

I wouldn't normally review an Early Access game but this deserves it because it 'works'. There are no problems with this release from a technical perspective, all that's missing is some content which the devs are / will be adding. 

What I love about this game is that a 'game'. Almost like a board / card game, the principles and mechanics are the same each time you play but the enjoyment and experience each time (which takes 10-20 minutes) is unique. 

This is not a co-op game, it's versus; a game in which you and up to three other AI or friends must battle it out to reach level 10 and defeat the boss. Only one player can be 'alive' at one time and the others must kill them by spawning as monsters or using traps to hinder the other's progress. 

Fantastic little game and I look forward to seeing what other additions are made.

I haven't read a whole lot of reviews, so I'm sorry if say some things that have been said a thousand times over.
That being said, I'd like to start off by saying that I love the concept of this game. All the items are super fun to combine and it's been fun seeing how long I can go with certain monsters without having to evolve them, and things like that.
Some things I'd think would be awesome if they were added:
-A Campaign: As fun as it is to grind through with a bot accosting me at every room, I would really enjoy some plot. It would be really cool if I was able to save my level and my items that I have at the time, and continue through the dungeons and such. I would definetly log a lot of hours on this game if such a thing were to exist.
-Gods: I'd like to kind of have a plethera of gods to choose from, with all their different minions and monsters. I'd also like to see some use of the actual gods themselves-- there are pictures of the gods, but no real reason to know what they look like. They're just a face. It would be really cool if there was a point in the game (of even a gamemode) where you get to play as the god you chose, and get to unleash your special kind of hell on your enemies.
-Heroes: As it stands now, when playing with four people, one person is pitted against three ghouls who get to try their best to rip their friend a new one. 11757813.review:
http://niveloculto.com/crawl-primeras-impresiones-pc/

Si estás leyéndonos, como poco estarás familiarizado con el oscuro mundo de los juegos de rol. No nos engañes, sabemos de tu secreto, pero no tienes de qué avergonzarte, que aquí todos estamos a la par. Como friki sotanero encubierto que sé que eres, no puedo dejar de recomendarte este pequeño juego.

Lo que nos propone es desde luego interesante, partiendo de los preceptos básicos del tan manido género de la espada y la brujería subterránea, se saca de la manga un sistema de juego verdaderamente atractivo: Mientras un jugador controlará al clásico héroe, con el objetivo de derrotar al temible engendro del averno de turno… los demás jugadores participarán como las bestias y trampas que pueblan la mazmorra.

Cuando no eres el valiente aventurero, manejarás a un espíritu que tiene la capacidad tanto de controlar los mil artefactos repartidos por cada nivel, como invocar su propio ejército personal de engendros de diverso pelaje. Éste es seleccionado al comienzo de la partida, y a lo largo de ésta puede evolucionar con un interesante sistema de repartición de puntos: Cuanto más evoluciona el héroe, más puntos tienen los demás a su disposición para ponerle las cosas más difíciles. El que logre derrotar al héroe, pasará a tomar su papel y a enfrentarse a sus antiguos aliados. Las traiciones están a la orden del día, y no siempre va a ser más rentable colaborar entre todos los espíritus, porque al final sólo uno será el vencedor.

Los niveles se generan de forma aleatoria, así como la disposición de las trampas y puntos de invocación. Cuando se alcanza el décimo nivel, si el jugador que controla al héroe se siente afortunado, puede intentar derrotar a la temible bestia que espera al final de su aventura. Estas fases son muy entretenidas, controlando cada jugador una parte diferente del monstruo (Sus dos brazos y su boca), haciendo de esta fase final un reto verdaderamente complejo.

Posiblemente inspirado en el juego de tablero “Descent” (Recomendadísimo), este sistema es terriblemente adictivo, sobre todo cuando hay más amigos involucrados (Hasta cuatro simultáneamente).

Crawl es esa clase de videojuego que parece predestinado al éxito en esta santa casa. A saber:

Gráficos pixelados preciosérrimos
Una jugabilidad “De la vieja escuela”: Con dos botones lo haces todo
Propuesta interesante, con un multijugador asimétrico bastante innovador…
Sin embargo tiene una serie de fallos que deberán corregir antes de la versión definitiva para ganarle la gloria eterna de nuestro sello de “Recomendado”.

El principal desde mi punto de vista es el desequilibrio que existe entre el héroe principal y el resto de jugadores, sobre todo al alcanzar la fase final. Existen tres intentos para derrotar al jefazo final, fracasando en el último se pierde automáticamente, incluso yendo toda la partida en cabeza. Es una verdadera lástima, porque el resto de elementos están calculados a la perfección para que las partidas sean igualadas hasta el final.

Si bien cuantos más participantes la acción se vuelve más divertida, también se vuelve caótica en la mayoría de los casos, sobre todo para jugadores menos experimentados. No estaría de más incluir algún tipo de marcador extra sobre cada jugador para saber en todo momento dónde nos encontramos.

Se echa en falta un modo multijugador online, que aunque nunca igualará la experiencia de compartir este juego codo con codo, es una posibilidad interesante que quizás deberían contemplar.

El último reto que deberán abordar en esta fase final del desarrollo es el ajuste de la inteligencia artificial. El nivel difícil es demasiado difícil, el normal demasiado fácil. Hasta aquí puede ser una cuestión de gustos, pero el comportamiento es muchas veces errático, quedándose atrapados en trampas relativamente sencillas pereciendo sin remedio. La experiencia está tan pensada en el multijugador que su experiencia en solitario desmejora completamente.

Aún con estos defectos, la propuesta de Crawl es sólida y contiene los ingredientes para convertirse en un grandísimo juego, sobre todo para jugarlo en compañía. No he tenido el placer de probarlo con mando (Es compatible), pero seguro que la experiencia mejora y mucho, a pesar de que los controles “Normales” (Con teclado el jugador uno, con ratón el segundo, no admite más jugadores simultáneos sin mandos), aunque algo extraños al comienzo, están perfectamente ajustados.
Su grandeza reside en la capacidad de ofrecer diversión instantánea a lo largo de cada partida (Que durará una media de 30 minutos) para cualquier tipo de público. Para ello, me propuse probarlo con un amplio espectro de jugadores a los que psicoanalicé rastreramente sin su consentimiento en lo que participaban de mi experimento. Mis conclusiones son las siguientes:

Borja Molina – Maestro inalcanzable

Contra este tipo no tenía demasiadas posibilidades. Que no hay manera oye, su capacidad de aprendizaje al teclado dejó hace muchos años de ser humana. Mientras yo sufría una paliza absolutamente vergonzosa, su gozo era palpable: El sistema de evoluciones es sencillo, pero con la suficiente profundidad para que sea divertido, los controles permiten auténticas virguerías con dos botoncitos, esa musiquilla de fondo tan “Vieja escuela”… Para él, auténtico delicatesen, con todos esos detallitos que pasan desapercibidos para la mayoría de los mortales, pero que marcan la diferencia entre un juego cualquiera y uno grande.

Álvaro Pereda – Némesis intermedio

La teoría y experiencia de juegos anteriores nos colocaba en un nivel como poco equivalente, pero ni con esas: También fui vilmente vapuleado. Mientras tanto, Álvaro gozó del ansia de coleccionismo que inspira el desbloquear nuevos elementos (Armas, criaturas, hechizos…) a cada partida, así como la ambientación general, lo cual es un logro considerable para un jugador bastante más casual que, salvo alguna excepción, no suele acercarse a este tipo de experiencias. Crawl no es exclusivo de fanáticos del píxel.

Xiao Ying – Dulces inicios

El reto final es uno muy especial. Mi hermana pequeña tiene 11 años, y empieza a cogerle gustillo a esto de los videojuegos. Qué mejor manera para tentarla e introducirla en este oscuro arte que incluyéndola en mi grupo de conejillos de indias.
Si bien costó un par de partidas que comprendiese del todo el mecanismo de juego, pude comprobar que realmente disfrutaba con él. Para mi regocijo pude ver reflejado en sus ojitos de neófita cómo de la confusión pasaba al puro vicio cuando lograba destronarme en el papel de héroe. Puede que incluso en el nivel más sencillo resultase un poco difícil para su edad, pero Crawl es una forma excelente de divertirse en familia y de paso, adoctrinar a los más pequeños en el camino que tanto nos apasiona: El del ocio digital.

¿Lograré engancharla del todo algún día? Aún está por descubrir, pero desde luego, este juego es perfecto para iniciar la llamita que acabe incendiando una pasión. Y de paso, compartir un rato excelente con cualquier tipo de amigo, de los más enterados a los menos espabilados, disfrutándolo en todo momento por igual. Sus puntos a mejorar no logran empañar un juego brillante en su sencillez.

11755894.review:
An amazing game and I hope & pray it takes off. Looking forward to the additions they plan to make: more bosses, more monsters, more evolutions, more weapons (!) and more tilesets. A ton of fun even solo against bots; if you have your PC hooked up to your TV - and can swing the amount of controllers required - this looks like an amazing party game, moreso than even maybe Guardian Heroes for the Saturn.

I hate to admit it, but perhaps it would be easier if Crawl found a home on the PS4 or XBone. It almost seems like it was natively designed for those systems (i.e. local multiplayer setup). The fast-paced competitive nature of the game reminds me of Power Stone 2 where the sole goal is to become MORE AWESOME than your peers. There is a certain 'equilibrium' to the leveling scheme that I very much enjoy and everyone can be involved & have fun whether they are the protagonist, monsters, traps, or just marionetting the boss. 

The pixel art-style does an amazing job of illustrating the action on-screen and also suggests careful choices of form and color. The level design of the dungeons (as mentioned before, they are planning more) feels like a fun slog through a Hero Quest scenario only not in boardgame iteration. Do I recommend getting it as it exists currently? Yes. Will it be better after it has time to ferment? Double yes.

11745061.review:
This is probably one of the most fun games I've ever played. Being a fan of both roguelike adventure games and oldschool 8 bit action and never being able to get my fill of either, this game stopped up the hole in my soul. Competitve game fan? This is totally for you. Friendships have almost been ruined. I've made my girlfriend's little brother rage quit several times  (claims Berserk is op, wants you to remove it. plz dont.) The huge amount of unlockables keeps me coming back for more. The variety in weapon animations, awesome/funny monsters (huge fan of the "flash my tentacles from under my robes" mind flayers :D) and interesting spell/item mechanics to keep everything spicy in the dungeon. 

 I know this is the earliest version of early release, but I have a few polish suggestions for you guys.

 If you could add twin-stick movement support for game pads that would be awesome. As it is now there are specific advantages that mice have over keyboard/gamepad, and vice versa, namely a full 360 degree aim for  mouse players and  ease of movement for kb/gp. I suppose for some people without game pads it wouldn't be as fair, but I would just as well go out and buy two more so everyone at my pad can enjoy perfect aim and movement. 

 Another thing, somewhat building off of the last suggestion is within the Kourok boss fight. Along the bottom of the screen to the left is a blind spot where, unless a mouse player is taking control of the eye beam, you cannot hit the challenger whatsoever. Perhaps you could add a scrolling left/right adjustment crosshair instead of the five direction spread for the eye beam? That way every section of the screen can be blasted with the beam. 

 Besides that as of now, I don't have any complaints. I don't think balance is an issue seeing shops/levels/monster spawns are all random, and everyone has access to the same types of spells/items/weapons/monsters. It's a perfect balance of luck/skill that allows a player to excel if they perform well, but can still be thwarted with a bit of teamwork and quick thinking from the ghosts.

 I can't wait to see how you guys expand on the dungeon aesthetics, more colors/props/texture and whatnot. If I could give any suggestions/requests on this, I think it would be interesting to see the dungeon floors randomized like the Infinite Layers of the Abyss from Dungeons and Dragons Grayhawk cosmology. Instead of having the floor's identities set in stone, just have the decor and name reflect each other and randomly generated (ie, acid themed floor "The Acrid Hive" or flesh walls/floors "Hall of Goosebumps.") Another roguelike game that has this element somewhat is a bullet hell  called Shoot First. Music reflecting the decor would be awesome too. 

 And one last request.. please implement a monster that's like the Devil from Heroes of Might and Magic 3 http://www.heroesofmightandmagic.com/heroes3/h3px/archdevil.gif

They are able to enter a burst of flame and teleport across the battle grid... maybe area damage when enter/exit the flames? The scythe would be awesome flavor too.

 Thanks for reading!~

11744418.review:
Thought it can be a lonesome crawl with the lack of online multiplayer, "Crawl," even in Early Access form, is a goldmine of local multiplayer value that shouldn't be missed.

In Crawl, you and 1-3 other players are all trapped in a dungeon guarded by a gargantuan monster. One of you will be a human fighter while the others are relegated to existing only as insubstantial phantoms. The hero is free to exlplore throughouth the dungeon, delving deeper into its catacombs as necessary to continue on in hopes of treasure, merchants, or a teleporter which can take the hero to the final boss room and either freedom or absolute destruction. As the hero moves from room to room, however, the phantom players can and will do everything they can to kill the hero, from possessing a variety of traps and summoning helper slimes to, most essentially, manifesting in the physical forms of any manner of beast from bear-trap summoning goblins to centaur archers to formidable gazer demons more than capable of slaying would-be-heroes. In the event that any phantom does kill the human opponent, they themselves will procure that player's humanity, spawinging as their own mortal fighter. This is the key pattern of the gameplay, with the hero being rewarded with experiencing points and the chance to purchase rare treasures from merchants nestled within the dungeon catacombs, while the phantoms are rewarded with stronger monsters and blood, which can later be turned into gold should they attain human form. The essential goal is to reach level 10 as the hero and, with the aid of an already impressive variety of unlockable weapons, potions, spells, and other items, reach the teleporter room instanced on each floor of the randomly generated dungeon and face the final boss in combat. The phantoms can possess parts of the boss's body to aid in the assault against the hero in an all-or-nothing battle. With victory, the hero is rewarded with freedom, but, should the hero be slain by his friends in his final assault, his name and likeness will forever be cast into ashes.

This game is still a work in progress but is still an easy product to recommend because all of the fundamental features and gameplay mechanics are already quite functional, entertaining, and polished. The core gameplay of killing your friends and becoming stronger in doing so is well-polished and, a few Early Access hiccups aside (including a lack of variety as of the time of this review and a forgivable level of question of balance with certain elements) is absolutely addicting in it's fast-paced flow of action, chance, and reward. 

The game is themed well with what could be called a haunted-arcade vibe that keeps the visceral action light and helps the player appreciate the charming and beautifully rendered retro-style graphics. While the look could understandably be considered "played-out" to some extent, in the current indie environment, but the atmosphere cast over the room by the up-tempo horror-midi soundtrack is both appropriate and exceptional.

With flawless controller support, easy-to-grasp yet hard-to-master brutal combat, quick 20-60 minute gameplay sessions and great mood I would absolutely recommend "Crawl" to any gamer who lives with other gamers or plays often with others in the same room. "Crawl" has no online support whatsoever and, while the bots are functional and helpful if you have less than 4 people, playing alone feels like more of an empty practice session at best. This game is just a blast with friends that you can easily show someone whose never played before a controller and play well into the night without becoming bored, and that's only with the content available as of this very early access build. For 9.99 I personally think that a better value is difficult to find, even here on Steam.

11739427.review:
[b] It’s been a long time coming, and it’s finally here. [/b]

In the caverns beneath Steam, all turn to CRAWL.

[b] I present to you . . . my review of CRAWL. [/b]

For time untold I had drifted, bored and alone. 

But now I watched as a simple developer once again trod the Early Access halls, developing a game that must be played.

I took possession of debit cards and PayPal sprung at my command, and when my Library increased a number by one, I could rise for a time as a player of a dungeon CRAWLer.

I summon my 360 controller and my gaming headset with a microphone for multiplayer. I wore them for leisure and abuse their usage and flung them at this game. Again and again, the bots cut me down! And I was tickled to see a trace of smugness in their eyes.

Did they think I would just play with bots down here?

[b] Play with 3 Human Players! [/b]

The others flanked with analogs, mice, and keyboards, and bled bots of their purpose. They were soon to die, these puppets of artificiality. But when will Powerhoof deliver the killing blow? If they could slay them now, the game would be reborn . . . filled with humans.

[b] Kill your friends and smile about it. [/b]

And as time went on, they fell! Purpose poured from their corpses and filled CRAWL to the brim and flashed praise and anticipation of multiplayer and flared my excitement, reborn. 

[b] Go to the forums; post your opinions and suggestions [/b]

Powerhoof was pleased with the suggestions we have given and rewarded us with content and updates. Taking these, I lobbied with a friend, for fun, excitement . . . and the urge to kill. 

[b] Only one gets out alive after all [/b]

With new vicious tools, I butchered friend after friend, growing ever delightful, but my friends grew also, and I could seldom hold my Humanity for long. Avatars were shredded underfoot as we fought for our prize: that one fading spark of opportunity.

We seized it!

We lost it!

We took it and we fled!

For Humanity alone held the difference. And stealing that prize, I hurled viscous blades and teeth and flame—

To a room most strange and very boss-like.

The eldritch stones split a ragged hole in the air, a gateway to the Final Boss above.

And winning . . . if you dare take 1 of 3 chances behind.

[b] ahem, ahem [/b]

Okay, now that that’s over with. The results are here:

[u]Graphics[/u]: Retro, not a bad thing really. It worked well here.

[u]Sound[/u]: Retro and somewhat repetitive. Like the olden games betwixt the 80s and 90s.

[u]Gameplay[/u]: Chaotic, but fun. Really fun. Future updates will have to require an indicator to keep track of your player’s location on the screen, though; colors alone are insufficient for something this fast-paced.

[u]Replay Value[/u]: Oh eff the hell YESSSSSSS!

[u]Verdict[/u]: A great buy for playing with friends and ganging up on each other. Also hope to play with strangers in multiplayer.

11712549.review:
[i][b]Platform:[/b] Ubuntu 14.04 with mid-high specs (see profile for details). Runs absolutely perfectly, with brilliant gamepad support using steamos-dkms xpad drivers.[/i] 

I have a soft spot for local multiplayer, and so I tend to add to basket as soon as I see a game tagged in this way. This review starts by saying that Crawl is potentially one of the best local multiplayer games I've played for a while. 

I played this game last night with my sister and parents (3 gamepads and myself, the unfortunate soul with the keyboard). I know we'll play again tonight, its that kind of game. Each time you play it begins like this, someone starts up the game, everyone taps their respective controller and occupies a slot, which the game cutely refers to as inserting a coin. You enter a 3 letter name, or choose a previously used one. Then you select a deity to worship (as of writing this review there are 3 deities; two instantly available and 1 unlockable). Your choice of deity decides what sort of beasts you can manifest yourself as to hinder the current hero. [b]The game begins.[/b]

The current hero is selected randomly from the up-to-4 players, and attempts to crawl through the dungeon as far as possible, amassing gold, buying new items and buffs. All the while, the non-hero players attempt to kill the hero by either manifesting as monsters by activating pentagrams that are one the floor of some rooms, "going-poltergeist" and possessing traps or turrets, or summoning slimes that they can stockpile by collecting dust. The non-hero player that kills the hero player gets to continue where the previous hero player left off, albeit without his buffs and items, these have to be collected individually. The object of the game, which you can only progress towards during your time as the hero, is to reach at least level ten so that you can open the boss portal, and defeat the boss. Aside from this the game has intervals everytime a player descends to a lower floor. During these intervals players receive [i]vitae[/i] points for everytime an opposing player levelled up on the previous floor. They can use these points to evolve their selection of beasts, making them stronger and a greater threat to opposing heroes. 

[h1]Why I like it so much[/h1]
The game offers a simple but very replayable mechanic. The non-hero players work together to try and kill the current hero, but ultimately want to beat the others to land the final blow and secure precious flesh-and-blood hero time. The current hero works to improve their items, spells and buffs so that they can fight off opposing players for longer. The struggle is fast paced, skillful and very fun. After level 10 players have the chance to nab the winner's position by choosing to fight the boss, but they only get so many chances, otherwise they finish last. As more bosses are implemented into the game, the risk of entering the boss portal will become even more interesting; what if its a boss you don't like and you only have one chance left? Maybe you should level further? But what if one of your opponents goes through? 

So so fun.

[EARLY ACCESS REVIEW:

Everything above, and SO MUCH MORE. Powerhoof went and added the narrator to the game, randomized the scenes at the beginning of the game (along with the narrator setting up the premise for that match) which really help build on the already fantastic mood, more music changes, additional ways for your disembodied adversaries to antagonize you, more monsters, more weapons, more everything.
