11683254.review:
I've really liked this game. So far I've been playing it for about an hour and here are some of my first impressions:

Gameplay: The gameplay itself is very sleek and smooth. Crawl resembles that of a button mashing arcade figher, which isn't a bad thing. There are two buttons you use to attack (primary and special) which just feels very satisfying. The concept itself is original as well, and that's something I haven't seen in quite a while. It's almost like a multiplayer dungeon crawler King of the Hill RPG. 

You battle your friends who are attemtping to kill you in order to revive themselves as humans and collect randomized dungeon loot along the way. If you or any of your friends finish off the human, they revive and then have their shot at completing the level. As the ghost characters, you take control of items and can summon monsters which you can evolve. At a certain point along the way you gain enough experience to fight the boss battle. Admittedly, the boss battle did come a little quickly and I had beaten the game before I knew it. However I noticed I unlocked a few items, so I know that coupled with the randomly generated levels means replayability is implied.

Art Style: I'm also a fan of this art style which is what first caught my eye. The animations are smooth and the characters are well drawn. I've never been the type to complain about pixel art as if it were an excuse to "real art"; it looks great. The only issue is I find myself backing away from the monitor to get the full view of some text which is otherwise a little difficult to read from up close.

Music: About what you would expect, pretty catchy but has a few points where it appears to stutter.

This game is in early stages, and it looks promising. So if it's good now, it can only get better.
It's only $10 right now so there's really nothing to lose by giving this a try.

I suppose the only thing I'd like to see a network multiplayer. And I understand the naivity of most people who make that statement and don't understand that networking isn't an easy task, but I could see this game being a blast at LAN parties and with friends who don't want to crowd around one screen or use mutliple controllers.

11645742.review:
After a year and a half of sifting through the boring, uninteresting titles on greenlight (I've viewed almost 1,000 titles), I finally stumbled across this huge surprise! The concept combined with the incredebly well done trailer and the fact it took less than 24 hours to be greenlit (not to mention, only two people were on this project) hooked me right from the start! I waited in anticipation for roughly 7 months (other people have waited for 2-ish years), so you'd expect that there would be A TON of hype, and I'm telling you right now, that all of that hype did not exceed that which this game deserved. To be completely honest, this is the most fun I've gotten out of ANY multiplayer game ever. This is an early access game, so it isn't finished (even though it's pretty much flawless in my opinion). They're going to be adding so much more content that I think may surpass the $9.99 value (which I feel is a perfect price for how much content there is currently). I urge you to consider supporting these two fine gentlemen in their quest to make the ultimate game (which may increase the chances of online multiplayer).

EDIT: Just thought I should add a few things based on what i've learned and also on the new update that came out a while ago.

I think it's imperative that everyone knows that the devs are actively interacting with the community on a weekly basis and sometimes more often than that. They are two very well mannered gentlemen that love to hear your ideas and definitely take every one of them into consideration. They actively post updates on development weekly and, like I said before, sometimes more often than that. There is promise of a trove of content that I'm pretty confident will come!

This update that came out in September practically doubled the content and they almost nailed the ballance on some of the earlier monsters from the first early access build. Just a few ballance issues with a few monsters from this new update need to be worked out, but that's hardly a concern of mine with devs as dilegent as these.

I should also note that the community that has been formed around this game is quite lovely and the people in it are very creative! Right now (Nov-december 2014) there's tons of excitement surrounding the release of a new update coming towards the end of December that includes a brand new boss and some other valuable content and the devs have maintained 100% transparency as far as their progress on the implimentation and testing of said boss and content. (aside from surprises that they wish to keep a secret). So you can just head on over to the forums and check that out. Drop in some suggestions if you'd like! (aside from Online Multiplayer, the devs have heard that over and over and over again) We'd love to have you!

EDIT EDIT: A lot has happened! A new boss has been added, new gods, more secrets, a new environment, and a wealth of monsters. They've added game changing mechanics and features that really change up where the game goes and can really shift the outcome of a match. They revamped the color pallet so it looks really nice and pretty now. Barney and Dave have really pulled it out in these last few months and have done nothing but improve the game and its value!

EDIT: Been a while. We've had quite a few updates since I last updated this review. Added a few monsters, traps, features, etc... I'd say my opinion hasn't changed at all. If it has, it's more positive than before. :)

11625474.review:
Here's a multi-part review discussing how the game works and then information about how my kids of various ages interact with the game.

-- How it Works -- 

The game is gorgeous and we all really love how it looks and sounds. 

Up to 4 players play locally (2 minimum). 1 person plays as a human, the other 3 play as ghosts. The human is seeking gold and experience. Once the human grows up to experience level 10, they make go into a special realm and fight a final end-boss. If they win against the boss, they are the dungeon survivor.

The ghosts, on the other hand fly around grabbing orbs. Once they collect enough orbs they're able to drop simple slime monsters into the map. If ANY monster is in a room, then the doors lock and the human must slay them. In some rooms the ghosts may be able to use Monster Symbols to take control of a larger monster and directly fight against the human. In some rooms, the ghosts can possess traps and trigger them against the human. If a ghost kills the human, they come into the game as the human and the dead player returns as a ghost.

Here and there you'll find a shop where you can upgrade your spells, weapons, or passive abilities.

The entire purpose of the game is to play as a human long enough to get to level 10, then escape the dungeon by killing the boss.

What's really fun, is that you only get 1 chance to fight a boss monster per dungeon floor. If you fail, or are not a high enough level, then you most descend further into the dungeon before you can try again. Between each floor in the dungeon, the players can exchange the power they've gained (granted when the human levels up) to evolve their selections of monsters, to effectively increase the difficulty of the next floor of the dungeon. 

This is definitely a lot of fun.

The final boss is a large beast that 3-players can take control of simultaneously against the human. If the players are on point, it's VERY HARD.

With only a few players, this game is very very simple. With 4-players actually trying to do a good job, the game is hectic and REALLY shines.

-- Family --

My 4-year old is a little unsure of the exact goals. But, she does like possessing items in the maps.  But, she gets tired of the game after 1 run-through.

The 9-year old has it all figured out and she does a great job. 

We really like playing this game 4-player as a family. The 4-year old gets a BIT distracted sometimes. But, overall she's ok. I definitely had to take her through the game a few times 2-player with the explicit purpose of showing her around before she could understand it.

-- Overall --

I can't wait till they add more boss types and dungeon diversity. This game has fantastic style and I trust these developers to make the right decisions for the game.

11622996.review:
This game by far is the most original game that I have seen ever since before games became re-hashed and ruined by franchise!  I saw this game on greenlight awhile ago (love at first sight), and I instantly wanted it. this game totally packs a new kind of competitive gameplay into dungeon crawlers. What is this game? it's multiplayer 1vs3 dungeon crawl, where 3 people can be the dungeon masters and one person will be the player; Here is the twist though: Once you kill the player you "steal" the players humanity and become the player yourself (the killed player becomes a dungeon master); which is totally new compared to the typical co-op experience you get in rogue-like games.  The goal of the game is to level up and gear up untill you can face the final boss. Whoever kills the final boss or has the most xp will win.  Another cool feature is that you can level up the enemies you can spawn as a dungeon master with a currency called vitae, which is gained by other players leveling up (Very good balancing technique, people who cant kill the player and remain at level 1 will gain more vitae than the others, so they can make their monsters super OP and finally kill the player). You can also collect small brown blobs that charge up the dungeon master's skill, and be able to summon slimes. However this game is not complete, and is still in early access; It also only supports local co-op at the moment (Not LAN co-op, its couch co-op), so For people expecting the multiplayer to be online should wait a little untill the developers can add it.  My score for this game is a definite 10/10, and it is completely worth spending $10 on.

How can this game improve?

-ONLINE MULTIPLAYER: in my opinion online multiplayer is this game's key to becoming even better. Even if it is peer-to-peer/Direct IP entry multiplayer, it will still be a major step for this game's future. I know Powerhoof said that multiplayer MAY be added later, but I do not feel comfortable with "may".  From what I've seen from powerhoof's website this is their first major release, and pretty much all the other games they released were point and click adventures. It's likely they are unexperienced with networking a game, and I dont blame them (I dont know how to add multiplayer to a game). I wish for the best they can get the help they need to eventually break through this barrier and add the feature this game would be perfected with.
-MORE SPAWNABLE MONSTERS: (maybe make several more monsters with different upgrade trees and have them randomly chosen when you choose which deity you worship).
-MORE SKILLS FOR THE GHOSTS: The dungeon masters/ghosts skill could be different for each deity (current skill just spawns slimes after you gather enough brown orb things). Some examples: Choosing Murkan gives you the ability to summon red crystals and traps, also blocks all the doors in the room, Choosing S'hrim gives you the ability to summon zombies/skeletons that do poison damage, and Choosing Teok gives you the ability to summon slimes/or maybe dwarfs with red cone hats :P  .
-MORE BOSSES: (could have them choosen randomly once you enter the boss portal).
Ideas include: Hydra: it lurks in a cave inside of a pool of water. maybe a plant boss of some sort who can roots come out of the ground and stab the player, (it would be in a forest-like cave).  Another boss could simulate games where you keep running right (the boss tails right behind you as you run) untill the boss is dead (similiar to the wall of flesh in terraria).
-CAMPAIGN MODE: let the player set the number of floors (10,20,30) before starting. after every 5 to 10 floors a portal will appear that lets you teleport to the boss which will be randomly chosen; after beating a boss in their respective lair a staircase will appear allowing you to continue,at the final floor there will be a giant red door which will lead to the final boss; the final boss will not appear in arcade mode (arcade mode is the original gameplay that you guys can play right now).  There would only be 3 tries for each boss (boss is still controlled by the ghosts (dungeon masters).  The bosses difficulty scales as you continue going down the floors (more health/damage).
-A POINT SYSTEM: this would be shown on the screen (for campaign mode and arcade mode), to be honest I do not like that the points are completly based on gathering XP which pretty much makes everything you did as a dungeon master pointless (pun-intended).  Points Should be added once you get xp and kills.  Each XP orb gives (1) points, every time the human player hits a monster he gets (1) point, points should also be given for damaging the human player in any room; this system would be similiar to how the blood currency is distributed - Example: 1st - most damage dealt (75)points, 2nd (50)points, 3rd (25) points, 4th - least damage dealt (0)points), killing a monster gives (25)points.
killing a player gives(100) points, killing a player with a trap gives (150) points, and lastly 
killing a boss gives (400) points.  This makes it so that even if you didnt kill the boss you can still win first place. The point counter would be shown at the top of the screen, but would be small enough so that it doesn't block any view of the game.
[optional] A message could be displayed under the players point interface, announcing why they got the points.
-DIFFERENT PORTAL MECHANICS: Don't have the portal generate on every floor, and make it so portals dont appear untill floor 5. It's kinda annoying when BOT's fail the boss, and just end up fighting him again on the next floor. Also If a player fights the boss already and loses he should have to wait a certain amount of floors before being able to fight it again (lets say 3) this way it gives the other players a chance to fight it if they are not level 10.
-MORE TYPES OF TRAPS: (Poison darts, mine launcher, spike floor where spikes pop out of the floor when the ghost activates it, and a trap that shoots out acid that remains on the floor for a bit.
-DIFFERENT RED CRYSTAL MECHANICS: A higher chance for red crystals to spawn in a room with traps, and a chance for red crystals to Re-appear in rooms if the player were to enter a room he has been in more than one time. (sometimes BOT's tend to run around FOREVER, and traps don't work well if the player can just run through the room which leads to this situation: The second you posses a trap the player has already left the room).
-MORE ARTISTIC VARIETY: as you go deeper into the depths the floors theme should change. As for what you could do I have a few Ideas. A floor everything is slightly dark and is illuminated by candles (the player and enemies will have a dim glow around them so the players can see where there characters are) The pentograms will also have a red glow. Different themed floors will change the look of the enemies slightly (different colors that match the floors theme). 
-MORE DECORATIONS: Pictures, procedurally generated furniture, knight statues, sword racks, etc.
-HERO CUSTOMIZATION: this game could have 3 different hero classes. The customization options (vanity) are unlocked after completing challenges (ie: kill 50 enemies to unlock the beholder mask).  You will also be able to choose your class and how your hero will look before choosing which deity to worship (which monsters you will have).

Well This is about everything I can think of that can be added or improved, I hope you can take my review to heart and add these features in the future even if not all of them.

11621399.review:
Al momento de abrir el juego, no sabia que esperar de el, pero lo que paso fue que redescubrí mi niñez

Crawl es un juego rogue-like en el que deberemos controlar un guerrero o un fantasma dependiendo la situación. El objetivo es huir del castillo matando al boss final, el cual este y los demás monstruos y trampas en el juego serán nuestros propios amigos.

El juego cuenta con la posibilidad de 4 jugadores en una misma pc pero no online, lo cual no es un defecto, por que busca volver a juntar a los amigos y reunirse a jugar algo y revivir la niñez, y en este caso tirar la amistad por la borda.

Uno de los jugadores deberá jugar como guerrero, defendiéndose de los demás jugadores en los calabozos.

A medida que vamos avanzando de piso iremos adquiriendo items para hacer nuestro personaje mas fuerte y así en el nivel 10 vencer al jefe de turno. Pero no solo deberemos mejorar nuestro guerrero, sino también nuestros monstruos dispuestos a arrancarle la cabeza a nuestro amigos, volviéndolos mas fuertes, mas rápidos y mas letales.

En el momento de luchar al jefe, uno se lleva una grata y terrible sorpresa al mismo tiempo. El jefe es nuestro mismo amigo, o en el peor de los casos, nuestros 3 amigos que nos harán la vida imposible.

El juego cuenta con un apartado gráficos retro totalmente hermoso, con personajes bien definidos, escenarios bellos a nivel estético y partículas apreciables.

La banda sonora como en la mayoría de los juegos Indies, es de las mejores, con un estilo retro al igual que los gráficos, nos hacen volver a la era dorada de los fichines.

Lo que mas se destaca es su jugabilidad, que con la compra de items y el ir progresando en las diferentes partidas para destrabar nuevos objetos le da cierta variedad al juego.

Lo que nos interesa es que el juego sea simplemente divertido, y te puedo decir que en este solo hallaras diversión.

Nota final: 9.5

Si lo que buscas son juegos Rogue-Like, Indie, o simplemente para jugar con amigos, no te arrepentirás de comprarlo.

11618339.review:
Ever since I've seen the teasers for this little game, I've been really eagerly waiting for its release. Final verdict is that it was definitely worth the wait, with the only disappointment being no online multiplayer (which hopefully comes). The whole concept is every fun and novel, in which all the maps seem to be procedurally generated as you play. One player starts off as the Hero, while the others play as three Ghosts, which have the ability to possess things throughout the rooms... such as pentagrams, for monster summons, and dormant traps, which can be utilized.

The object for the players is simple: Be the first to get up to XP Level 10 so you can open up the portal to face the final boss and fight for your escape. A Hero earns their experience by killing the opposing players who take monster forms, but there's also a second form of specialized experience, particularly useful to the Ghost players: Vitae. Every time a Ghost player causes damage to the current Hero, they earn this currency, which can be used in a variety of ways, like taking a warp to the floor's shop, pay tribute to an idol for quick cash, or... if you're feeling more offensive... use it to upgrade your monsters. That melee skeleton not cutting it for you? Upgrade it to a bow skeleton for heavier, ranged damage. Being an early access game, I can see there's still plenty more to be made for this game, so I can see this system being expanded on quite nicely. Even better, winning the game makes unlocks more things to use in the game, which helps increase the replay value here.

My only gripe is the lack of online multiplayer, which could make this game's popularity explode greatly, but even then... If you have four controllers to plug into your PC? Get this... NOW. It's definitely a riot of a local multiplayer party game. :>

11617165.review:
Wow, what a surprise. I'm not usually one to pick up early access games as I would prefer to play a finished project, but after seeing this on the Humble store, I  immediately fell in love with the pixel/glitch art style. I checked out the gameplay video and decided to give it a chance.
      Crawl starts up as if it's an old school arcade game, asking you to insert coin and enter you initials. Up to four players can play via couch co-op (no online unfotunately, but I think the fast paced gameplay lends itself better to local co-op) using keyboard, mouse or controllers. One player starts as the human character advancing through the dungeon collecting money, loot or finding the exit to the dungeon. The other three player take control of ghosts who can summon creatures or possess traps in the dungeon with the purpose of destroying the human character. Once a ghost player has killed the human player, they become the human. End game happens once a human character destroys the main boss.
      As you progress, your character levels up and can buy weapons and equipment that change the way the game is played. In between levels, you can upgrade the monster creatures you send out as a ghost, making the game more difficult as you progress. It's very nicely balanced and I never felt like one player was too strong or weak against other players. While this game is meant to be played with multiple players, I found single player with bots surprisingly challenging, and at times forgot I was playing against the computer.
      I highly recomend Crawl if your looking for a frantic couch co-op game to play with your friends, or just looking for a fast paced arcade style game to play by yourself. With the added promise from the developers of more creatures, dungeons, and items to be added in the future, as well as the $10 price tag, you really can't go wrong with this one.

This game came out of no where.  I saw the trailer for the first time today and yelled "SHUT UP AND TAKE MY MONEY!!"  Well... they got my money.  Within one hour of gameplay I realized that it was money well spent.  It is a great local co-op party game!  I'm not even sure what to compare it to...

It's a dungeon crawl (get it?) but only one person is the hero at a time.  The other people play the monsters.  When they kill the hero, they become the hero who then joins the monsters.  As you level up, you level/upgrade your hero and your monsters at the same time.  You basically play until the game ends one way or another (hero wins or monster wins).  The winner is the person scored the most points along the way.

The pixel graphics are beatiful.  The whole feel of the game is nostalgic, yet fresh at the same time.  It only takes a few moments to figure out what is going on.  The polish on this game is already amazing (even in the early access phase).  It's already a complete game in my opinion, but I can't wait to see what content gets added to the full release!  I could totally see different dungeons with different bosses to play.  You get to play as the boss when the hero fights him by the way.

Lot's of fun.  Buy this!!

11605219.review:
Get it! Go! Now! Take it! Have it! Love it!

Crawl's a short-session action roguelike. It takes thirty minutes or so to play a single round, and win or lose, you'll net new unlocks to change up future crawls. Fast-paced and capable of hammering home a gloriously tooth-grinding need to win, even just against the AI bots, Crawl is exactly what it looked like in that first video that took us all by storm months ago (and if you haven't seen that, watch it at once, it's on this very page).

Most impressive is the game's catchup mechanics. Each player has three tracks of monsters that they level up from lowly worms into terrible dragons, from cackling skeletons into...whatever that giant goddamn black knight thing is, seriously, he's worryingly huge. The "Vitae" these upgrades require is earned when your -opponents- level up. That's right: The further ahead one player's human shape gets, the nastier the beasts he'll find himself facing, and those who've been struggling will have the most worrying monsters of all. I was a little unclear on how the game decided what tier to spawn you at, but it seems to have a similar catchup mentality (I saw an AI who was wayyy behind the rest of us spawn as a top-tier dragon twice in a row).

It does a lot to keep the humanity ball passing around. After reaching level ten (which is not the cap, if there is one), that player, when human, can use one of the portals scattered around the dungeon to take on the boss. If he loses, he's ejected, but gets to stay human (if a human at terrifyingly low life). The game can't drag on forever, though: The third time the boss is engaged (by any player) the portal explodes in a totally metal portal explosion. Defeat of the human player now means the end of the game, a consolation prize for the ghosts and absolute devouring of the foolish human who'd tested his might and failed.

It all comes together really well. The joyful rage of getting your killing blows on the human stolen by an UNWORTHY GHOSTLY ALLY who hadn't contributed much is palpable, and the satisfaction at pulling apart the creatures as a human and getting your big, glitzy retro levelup effects is real. Both modes of play are fun, which is probably the key factor here--dying sucks, but hey, on the other hand, now you get to be a giant fuckoff black knight and make your friends bleed. And that blood spilled when playing as a monster gets saved up, to be converted into gold when you next find yourself human. There's never a lazy moment: It's constantly important that you be pummeling your friends (or computers).

There's an almost infinite amount that could be done with this game. Items could be added forever. Alternate bosses, more sets of monsters to pick from, hideous new traps, diversified level pallettes--the paging space is almost numbing. So buy this game! Encourage our antipodean friends to make more out of it!

11605044.review:
Never before have I felt that a game truly defined a brawler co-op+VS experience until crawl.
Games such as castle crashers and even the old final fights had some 
sort of co-op and some some sort of vs but traversing the level felt
exactly the same as if you were doing it single player with a tiny
taste of competitive on the side. Crawl doesn't do this, playing alongside
your friends means having to keep an eye on every single thing each
of your friends does. Their level, their money, who's hanging back to
jump in and steal the kill, who's flinging an all out assault. It's
extremely enthralling and keeps you on your toes throughout each
and every game, you even start to get some of, what I like to call,
the mario party aspect. You start resenting and shouting at your
friends. "WHY DID YOU HAVE TO FIGHT THE BOSS, IT'S OUR LAST TRY!?"
"DAMMIT I WAS GONNA BUY THAT WEAPON!" etc, etc.
Crawl is a great game not only in multiplayer with your friends
but even in single player, with advanced and clever AI that
seem to know what you'll try before you try it (although they
do get caught on boxes sometimes) making even single player
quests an exciting experience.
I've been playing on off since release and even I still haven't 
unlocked everything which means there is a lot in this game to
obtain and because it's still being built even MORE will be added.

I hope you consider Crawl as the multiplayer experience of the year
and buy yourself something fun and exciting. 
With some frogs, demons and just a dash of Lovecraftian horror
Crawl is a great game that deserves your time.

11598975.review: Crawl is an amazing Dungeon crawler type game. One player controls The Hero and the other players play as Ghosts. The Ghosts have to possess traps and become monsters to try and kill The Hero. Whoever lands the final blow to The Hero becomes The Hero. There is also currency in the game, You can get blood by hurting The Hero as a Ghost and you get gold by finding chests. While exploring you can find a blacksmith where you can buy better swords, spells and you can kneel down to an idol that takes all of your blood and makes it gold. That was a basic rundown of Crawl. Before you buy it though, it is only local co-op as of today but the devs said that online is a possibility. I recommend this to everybody who likes a fun multiplayer experience.

Crawl is a fun and new take on the classic dungeon crawler. However, instead of having a party of heroes, venturing into a dusty pit of doom, you have one hero and a party of evil ghosts, trying to kill him and thus take his place as the hero. The version I've played just before the early access started, had three evil gods to worship, each with his own set of horrible upgradeable monsters + tons of magic items for the hero to invest in, including madness inducing swords. And there's more to come!

If you love playing with a bunch of friends, this game gets my highest recommendation, even with the content at Early Access release. 11588257.review:
Below you'll find a written and video impression of the game.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e_2zCZm3sLY
Crawl takes the idea of dungeon crawling to a competitive level. The game features an unique A-symmetrical competitive design where it's a hero against a team of ghouls. Though the ghouls can not directly harm the hero, they can spawn mobs, turn into greater mobs, and take control of traps to hinder the hero's progress. Though the ghouls have the common goal of killing the player, they are still in competition with each other to land the killing blow. To break it down, it's an XP race, and you can't gain XP unless you are the hero, and you can only become the hero if your ghoul lands the killing blow. This dynamic presents some very interesting and unforeseen strategies.

The game's art, music, and sound design are all top-notch, and worthy of praise. The pixel art is detailed and well animated, while the music and sound design is distinctly 16 bit. Overall the game keeps to it's theme quite well, and it's certainly not too hard on the eyes.

Though the game features some very unique and interesting ideas, and top shelf presentation, it's not with out it's flaws. Currently, as of this impression, the game only features local multiplayer. For a game that is very multiplayer focused, this is a huge sin. Those who have people close at hand, Crawl is an easy recommendation, but if don't, then you have to consider your purchase more. I've played this solo and still enjoyed it greatly, but after a while, bots are bots, and once the gimmick of the unique mechanics is settled away, boredom can eventually set in. I can see how this is much more interesting with live people, unfortunately I never got to experience this very important aspect of the game due to it's lack of online.

Overall all Crawl is a very uniquely designed competitive game that is both engaging and beautiful. Even at it's current early state the game feels stable and "finished". Any new updates from this point will feel more like extra content, than the game making up for obviously missing parts. This is a good thing :) It's just too bad about the lack of online. With out it It's not as easy of a recommendation as it deserves to be, but hopefully in the (near) future, that will be rectified.

Pros:
- Uniquely designed competition / mechanics
- Great presentation
- Easy to understand, but challenging

Cons:
- No online... :(

The monsters evolve after each floor, getting tougher and tougher, and eventuallly, they will kill you, you only get "xp" (or vitae, as its called ingame)  to evolve your monsters if the other players level up, so it has a massive competition side to it, if you survive the whole floor, and not be killed once, then you probably wont be able to evole your monsters. So what do you get? The other players are getting the advantage... but not really, you have weapons, swords and bows and javelins/spears to fight them off, some quicker some slower but more damage, there are many, many many many weapons to this game to kill your undead enemies, atleast, i think there are.

Each time you finish a game, more content gets added (it of course tells you what once you beat it) like more weapons, traps, gods and more, so if theres not enough content for you, dont you worry there will be more.

So your a monster and you kill the player, whoever got the last blow turns into the human, and you got it, what do you do? go to the blacksmith shop, or find it, because every time you hit the player, you earn "blood" which you can give to a statue in the blacksmith shop. the statue is happy from the blood you spilled, and rewards you, with money, that you can use for weapons or purchase a "spell" that replaces your dodge roll.

So this game offers much, and is definatley worth ten bucks, infact i think that is a lower price than what this game offers, and the fact this game is going to ofer more in the future... well thats just great.

인간을 죽인 몬스터는 인간이 되고 그걸 반복합니다.

이 게임은 던전 크롤링 보다는 플레이어끼리 싸워나가며 서로 인간이 되며, 경쟁하는 게임입니다.

11582951.review:
1人がヒーローを操り、残りがモンスターを操る最大4人のローカル専用対戦ゲーム。
現状はローカルで複数人で遊べる環境なら強くおすすめする。(Botとのプレイも可能)

ヒーローはダンジョンの部屋をまわってゴールを目指す。
一方、モンスターはいかにヒーローを倒すかを競う。
モンスターがヒーローを倒すと、止めを刺したプレイヤーがヒーローになってゲームが続行。
最終的にゴールまで辿り着いたヒーローのプレイヤーが勝者となる。

・ヒーローができること
ダンジョンの探索
モンスターを倒して経験値をためるとレベルアップ
オブジェや宝箱からゴールド入手
ゴールドがたまったらショップで武器やアイテムを購入

・モンスターができること
各部屋の魔方陣やオブジェからモンスターを召喚
各部屋のトラップを発動
ステージの合間にモンスターを強化

モンスターは3カテゴリからランダムで召喚できるが、開始直後に召喚できるモンスターは非常に弱い。
しかし、ヒーローにダメージを与えると手に入るポイントを使ってモンスターの強化が可能。強化するモンスターのカテゴリ、強化後のモンスターを2種類から選択できたりと、かなり自由度がある。

序盤はヒーローのほうが性能が高く無双できるが、何段階も強化したモンスターは非常に強力になり終盤は激しい戦いになる。
もちろんヒーローも装備を整えることで連続技や魔法が使えるなど強くなる要素はある。

面白いのは、モンスターのポイントをゴールドに換えてヒーローを強化できるため、
モンスターを強化するか、ヒーローを強化するかというプレイヤー間のかけひきが重要と思われる。

操作方法は上下左右とボタン2個。ボタンは通常攻撃と特殊アクション。
特殊アクションはキャラごとにドッジだったり飛び道具だったり様々。
ゲームパッドは360パッドとロジテックパッドで動作確認
キーボードとマウスでもプレイできるとのこと。

色々とゲームシステムが考えられており、現時点でも面白いゲームだが、今後もじっくりアップデートをしていくらしい。
オンラインマルチの実装も不可能ではないらしいので期待したい。

11581959.review:
We’ve all played RPG’s before with friends at our side, but what happens when your friends control the monsters instead? Developed by the two man team over at Powerhoof, Crawl is a local co-op dungeon crawler for up to four players, and provides the answer to that very question.

In a rather interesting turn of events, one of you controls the hero, slaying monsters, gaining levels, and buying loot, while the other 3 players use ghosts to possess traps or summon monsters with the simple goal of killing you to become the hero instead. The point of Crawl is to survive long enough to reach level 10, then activating a portal to the final boss encounter. The player that reaches and defeats the final boss first wins the game.

If you have local friends who frequent your house, Crawl is an insanely good time. Its short 30-minute games, combined with its accessible pick-up-and-play control scheme, make it ideal for parties or for larger groups of people to pass the controllers around. However, if you’re running solo, you’ll most likely grow tired of fighting the A.I. rather quickly and there isn’t anything to do after that.

11578002.review:
Ok, so I've never done any review. Ever.

But this game deserves it. So let's get started.

[h1] First of all, what is Crawl? [/h1]

Like the name suggests, along with the pictures, you might understand that it's your usual dungeon crawler. But it isn't.
It IS a dungeon crawler. But not in the likes of Diablo or Torchlight. It's more of a skilled-hack 'n' slash-dungeon crawler.
And TBH, as a fan of dungeon crawlers, this is the best one I've ever seen. 

I might also add that I may have a little bias about it because of the god damned amazing music/teaser trailer. But I digress.

As I've said before, it's not your usual dungeon crawler. And there's also another reason because of that. It's not open world and it's not story driven. It's an arcade game.

And it does it really well. The game, as you may already know if you're reading this review because you want to be sure that the game is nice, is a local co-op/versus game.

"But Baron! I don't have any friends! I'm a god damned loner!"

Well they added some bots which you can play against for "practice while you're waiting for your friends". And they're also going to add multiplayer in the near future. So that's good. Because I'm also a loner.

[h1] How's the gameplay? [/h1]

It's good, 10/potato.

Just kidding. The gameplay is absolutely amazing, but to be played at its best you NEED a controller. Which isn't a problem FOR ME, but might me a problem for the people who can't afford to buy one. Any controller that is supported by steam will do. But personally I prefer to use a PS3 controller with the scarlet crush drivers.

As I've said at the start of this review, the game is part hack 'n' slash. And it's a blast. The controls are responsive and easy to learn. It's literally just two buttons. I've never found myself saying "God damn it, I didn't want to do that!", if I died it was 90% of the times because of the skill of the bots or because I wasn't good enough.

The only problem about it might be that they made the button to attack also the button to "use" stuff. I've found myself sometimes entering the final boss battle by mistake with little health remaining and dying by the hands of the bots controlling the boss.

[h1] How are the graphics? [/h1]

Well, I really don't know, I don't have eyes to see a god damned PICTURE ON THE STORE PAGE.

[h1] TL;DR? [/h1]

Do you like co-op fast paced hack 'n' slash dungeon crawlers games? Then this is for you, I guess, I've never heard of games like this, but whatever, everyone has their own fetish.

[h1] Gib scor plz [/h1]

KK bb, from a scale from 1 to 10:

Music: 10

Gameplay: 10 [seeing yourself getting raped to death just to kill the same bot that killed you is an amazing feeling]

Graphics: 10

Overall: 10

On a side note, it runs on my toaster, 10/10

11571618.review:
I've never been much of an online multiplayer kind of guy, in my household we couch co-op and that's just always been our tradition. Playing side by side with friends and family, bulky plastic controllers in hand is a lost art and one that deserves a lot more attention. We've seen many titles try and bring back this passion for a more human gaming experience in the living room recently with successful titles like [i]Nidhogg[/i] and [i]TowerFall Ascension[/i] reminding us of that feeling of intense person-to-person competition and friendly rivalry we were able to get with console games in the past. With the rising popularity of online PC gaming where does this close and personal human interaction go, is there still room for the local multiplayer experience?

[i]Crawl[/i] thinks so, and it answers the call by pitting man against monster, friend against friend, in the darkest and nethermost of dungeons of the most replayable player on player brawler to date. You will die many times by the hands of your most trusted acquaintances but as Bram Stoker once wrote, [i]"We learn from failure, not from success!”[/i]

The heavy, ominous chip melody evokes a feeling of terror and haste as the monsters swarm about the mortal player for their own chance at sweet humanity, and must tear it from the cold dead hands of their cohort before losing the chance to turn the tables. All sound direction is incredibly fitting, with voice samples sounding as if straight out of an authentic 80's pinball machine or arcade cabinet. Suspenseful horror aesthetics and the doom-impending tone of the music compliment the tension, chaos and madness of the multiplayer struggle for supremacy all too well.

You begin by choosing one of the Gods of unspeakable horrors, determining which set of ghastly familiars you will be taking control of and leveling up throughout your mad grab for humanity. Blood is gained as you spill it from your human target to be exchanged for gold and used at merchants to buy an array of varied equipment and skills, ranging anywhere from double-daggers with fast speed but short reach to floating glyphs that fire lasers on your command. This puts a lot of motivation on the monster players to bleed the human as much as possible, in order to better prepare themselves with loot once stealing back humanity. 

Monsters themselves add one of the deepest layers of the game, each with branching sets of evolution trees to play around with. Evolving your monsters is dependent on Vitae which is acquired through enemy humans leveling up, and keeps the playing field between the two more or less balanced. Honestly, though, I don't think anyone is capable of explaining the mechanics as well as [url=http://youtu.be/2_3xrqjTyes]the trailer[/url] does.
 
Before even getting a chance to sink my teeth into [i]Crawls'[/i] gritty and visceral gameplay I couldn't stop watching the trailer, it sent chills down the spine. It's really the most captivating I'd seen in awhile and the narration nails the urgency of your doom-ridden quest. I had to know how such an effective voice actor was acquired. 

After questioning the developers on the subject, it turns out that the narration wasn't hired or professional help at all, but the contributions of a close friend they had previously worked with and this fact just fortified in my mind the strong bonds behind the creation of the game and it's origin of a personal and human nature. According to Dave, [i]"The voice actor from the trailer is a friend of ours, Adrian Vaughan. He’s a 3d artist who we met at the first game studio that Barney and I worked at together. He’s one of those guy’s who’s always putting on funny accents and I got him to do some voices for an adventure game I made for a competition (called [u]The Unicated[/u])."[/i] 

Apparently they weren't expecting the trailer to gain as much attention and praise as it did for the game, as Dave goes on, [i]"We were incredibly pleased with how the trailer went, we had no idea if it would be received well or not while we were working on it. We thought it might be too long, or wordy, and it was difficult getting a balance of the tone and the explanation of the game. We’re so glad we did it that way now though."[/i]

[i]Crawl[/i] clearly has some heavy retro arcade influences, and upon discussing the game with the developers the sources of inspiration were confirmed. [i]"For Barney, two big inspirations were [i]Bomberman[/i] and [i]Gauntlet[/i], and they shine through in the gameplay most of all."[/i] and with it's blend of the dungeon delving hack'n'slash action of [i]Gauntlet[/i] and the rage-inducing competitive aspect of [i]Bomberman[/i], I'm inclined to agree that both of these examples shine through. He continues to explain, [i]"We’ve grabbed inspiration from tonnes of games though really, old RPGs like [i]Legend of Zelda[/i], the gothic tone of the first [i]Diablo[/i], and a bit of [i]Dark Souls’[/i] brutality to name a few."[/i] All being perfect representations of where [i]Crawl[/i] takes its grim and savage direction.

This is a game that will bring together the most unsuspecting of players, serious-minded people who don't even game will forget themselves and get caught up in the blood-boiling clash for mortality. Not only does it bring friends together but it tests the limits of your friendship, edging you closer to feelings of vengeance on your once trusted peer. Similar to the feeling of having the excitement of 1st place in [i]Mario Kart[/i] swiftly crushed and ripped from you by a friend lucky enough to get that one Blue Shell and take your place of glory, leaving you with nothing but the desire to track them down and kick their ass.

[i]Crawl[/i] is a game made by friends, for friends. A multiplayer experience unlike anything seen since the 90's. A game made by two close compatriots who wanted to rediscover and reinvent what gathered them around the tube so many years ago. The kind of entertainment we've lost sight of after so many years of growing into adults, getting jobs and families, and in general forgetting what made us really have fun as kids.

Despite being its best around warm-bodied experiences I can still wholeheartedly recommend the game even for those who might be too busy or too far from friends to partake in the multi-person mayhem. With bots and their adjustable difficulty, I was still kept on the edge of my seat during every attempt to steal the victory from the intelligent computer opponents. With even more balancing on the horizon as well as constant updates to content, and a serious community involvement from the developers on forums there is pure determination shown in shaping the game how players want and proves that [i]Crawl[/i] is already one of the shining examples of Early Access done [b]right[/b].

11470418.review:
Full disclosure: review copy provided by developer/publisher!

For the longest time now publishers and devs have decided that gamers no longer have friends in real life... our social gaming lives exist solely online. This has lead to the downfall of “couch co-op,” with many multiplayer games being released completely lacking any local multiplayer feature. It's time we say enough is enough! I still have buds over to play video games, real ones that stay too late and often drink too much (Hey Will! Sure, what kind of party would it be if you didn't vomit everywhere?).

The devs of “Crawl” remember the yesteryear of “couch co-op” and they hear our cries. Like silent, brooding Batman-y types they're the heroes local multiplayer deserves; and they're paying an homage to classic, “Gauntlet” type dungeon crawlers. The concept is simple: you and up to three friends select a god to represent (you can also use bots that are HIGHLY competent). Each god represents different creatures you'll take the form of during battle so choose wisely. Then you're dropped into the first level of the dungeon. One player is the hero, the rest of you are douchebag specters of death who's sole purpose is to thwart the crawler with traps and dark symbols through which you become corporeal monsters. First player to kill the crawler becomes one themselves, and the cycle continues. Be warned: “Crawl” has friendship killing potential the likes of which haven't been seen since “Mario Party,” “Mario Kart,” and the little-known “Mario Fucks Your Friend's Mother.”

Throughout each dungeon you'll gather gold to spend on upgrades and weapons. As you clear each section you'll use vitae gathered to “evolve” your monsters, branching off into more powerful ranged, magic, and warrior types. Each level also features an ominous Stonehenge-like monument pulsating with blue magicka that unlocks the final boss once you or one of your former pals reach level 10. At that point you can choose to face the big baddie. You'll get a cool battle strategy hint in the boss fountain room before entering the arena. Each of your friends (and bots) will possess the boss, working in tandem to stop you from winning by using a variety of attacks. Assuming you win it's game over, you won! Assuming you lose another friend gets a shot. But each time you face the boss you do damage to the monument and if no one wins you will all game over.

“Crawl” is beautiful, stylish, and a blast to play. The monsters are really cool, the music is most excellently retro, and when playing against three friends (or AI bots with the difficulty increased) it is a challenge. The devs (now famously) sent out a cool apology gif when they had to delay “Crawl” briefly – which to me is a good indicator that they will work with the community to continue expanding and polishing an already excellent core game. 

ALAS, I have one major gripe. It isn't a deal breaker, not for me anyway. But at the moment there is no ONLINE multiplayer. Now I know what I said earlier. I miss the bygone days of local mutliplayer and I'm happy to see it as an option. But I still have lots of friends I want to play this with online, ones that live far away in mythical places like California and Canada. I want to live in a world where I don't have to choose. I want both, perhaps greedily. Hopefully we'll see it implemented. Otherwise keep in mind this is Early Access. At the moment there appears to be one final boss and only three deities to choose from. But what is there is highly polished and very fun. They'll be adding more end bosses and deities throughout development. I also hope to see more variety in the dungeon layouts and color schemes. But as it is this is an excellent title. For ten bucks I easily, heartily recommend this.

Reviewer's Note: “Mario Fucks Your Friend's Mother” probably doesn't exist. Probably.

11441296.review:
Bei Crawl findet man sich in einem sehr spannenden Multiplayer-Spiel, bei dem ein Spieler die Rolle des Menschen übernimmt und 1-3 Gegenspieler versuchen, ihn mit Fallen oder Monstern zu vernichten. Sollte es einem Spieler gelingen die HP des Menschen auf 0 zu reduzieren, so tauschen sie Rollen. Das ganze geht so lange, bis ein Spieler als Mensch Level 10 erreicht, und den Endboss besiegt ODER wenn der Boss insgesamt 3 mal von den Spielern herausgefordert, aber nicht bezwungen wurde. In dem Fall gewinnt der Spieler mit dem höchsten Level.

Im Laufe des Spiels kann man seine Monster mit Punkten aufwerten, die man durch Level-Ups der Gegner bekommt. Durch Schaden, den man am Menschen anrichtet bekommt man Bluttropfen, die man gegen Geld und somit gegen bessere Waffen oder andere Statboni eintauschen kann.

Dank des wechselseitigen Spiels kann man nie sagen, wer nun gewinnen wird und es bleibt permanent spannend. Vielleicht sieht es schlecht aus, weil ein Spieler schon level 9 erreicht und man selber auf Level 2 rumgurkt, jedocht kann man dann -wie oben erwähnt- seine Monster verstärken und kann wieder den anderen Spielern das Leben schwer machen.
Nach einer kompletten Runde (die schnell mal 30-45 Minuten dauern kann) schaltet man weitere Monster und weitere Items frei. Dadurch hat man Grund, das Spiel auch öfter mal anzupacken.

Ich hatte bisher enormen Spaß mit dem Spiel und kann es nur empfehlen (Ja, ich habe zwar keine Spielzeit auf Steam, jedoch habe ich es lokal mit einem Freund auf einem anderen Account gespielt)

Leider fehlt dem Spiel noch ein Online-Multiplayer, und so muss man sich mit Local-Multiplayer oder Singleplayer gegen Bots zufrieden geben. Der Entwickler hat jedoch angekündigt, dass ein Online-Modus relativ wahrscheinlich ist. Das Spiel ist ja noch im Early Access.
Auch mangelt es zur Zeit noch an Items und Räumen usw, jedoch ist auch das noch in Planung.
